post_b.text:
Do's and Don'ts in your job search I see a lot [!!!] of mistakes in the past few months and in this kind of arena you should be in your best shape! These mistakes cost a lot. #Don 't- Upload a LinkedIn post that says you've been looking for a job in the past 6 months and that everyone rejects you/ treats you unfairly in the hiring process.  #Why ? You are your own brand! If you are a brand you should emphasize your professional skills by sharing interesting content and showing interesting projects. You can get empathy from friends but LinkedIn isn't the place for that. #What  should you do instead? Ask a friend to upload a post about you as a reference or focus on side projects and show them on LinkedIn. #Don 't- Use the "Open to work" LinkedIn frame  #Why - Although it seems like a cool feature, I know recruiters who say they decline to connect requests from people with the frame in order to prevent inconvenience because they do not have jobs to offer. #What  should you do instead? Open the "let recruiters know you are open to new opportunity button", it's discreet and won't show up to recruiters at your company. And yes, marketing-wise it looks much better. All of this info is based on my thoughts research and experience. Feel free to share your opinion. Good luck!  #Jobs   #HR

post_a.text:
#Failure is not good. Failure is the worst thing possible. You feel sick. You feel like you’re going to die. You feel like if you don’t die you might kill yourself. There is absolutely nothing good about failure. And there’s nothing you can pretend to learn from failure. Lately, we’ve been living in the Golden Age of Failure Porn.  Everyone wants to share their story. Everyone wants to “fail forward”. You can’t learn anything from failure because don’t forget that every single moment in your past has added up to that one moment in your present – where you are lying on the floor moaning your painful and abysmal failure. Stop whining. And stop using the word “failure”. Blah! Here are better things to learn from. Failure has many cousins. Learn from one of the cousins: Curiosity: When something happens and you don’t understand why, then ask, “Why?” Keep asking questions. Clearly, something confusing happened. Ask and ask and ask. Guess what will happen: you will get answers...  http://bit.ly/2rIVf4t

post_b.text:
As someone who grew up in a low income and immigrant household, being invited to speak at the Peninsula College Fund's Career Day at Visa was such an humbling experience. It's also refreshing and inspiring to see tech brands like Visa taking the lead in furthering this cause and in the process positively shaping the future of such a deserving, yet underserved group of determined and talented students.  I entered Silicon Valley with no ties to tech—both of my parents never attended high school. Through personal branding and platforms like LinkedIn, I have been able to develop a meaningful network of mentors that has radically transformed my career and life. While low income students may not grow up being taught the importance of networking, college is the best time to change that for the better. tl;dr (too long; didn't read): Treat your personal brand as a tapestry of experiences and relationships, not a transactional tool. When done with purpose and authenticity, your personal brand will compound over time, and put you in the power position to be discovered and unlock disruptive opportunities. Thanks for the invite  Sonia Sng ! Fantastic program  Denise Villamil  &  C. Phillip Powell, MPA .

post_a.text:
Ghosting has to stop.  A company gets in touch with you, inquires about your availability, and then - poof. Vanishes. You go to a job interview, you feel OK/good about the process, they tell you they’ll be in touch. And then… crickets.  It’s not only companies. Candidates do that all the time. Answering and then ignoring, scheduling a job interview and not showing up, not returning any calls.  Ghosting usually saves you 1-2 minutes of inconvenience. But it brands you as a douche forever.  No one likes uncertainty. Whatever you are - a candidate, a recruiter or a sourcer - treat people like you want to be treated. Be responsible. Learn to say ‘sorry, but no’. Stop ghosting. #ghosting   #career   #hr   #people

post_b.text:
As you prepare for your next meeting ask yourself the following questions: · Why do we need to meet? · What is the purpose of the meeting? · Is this an informational, decision-making, problem-solving, brainstorming, team-building, or instructional/skill-building meeting? Or a combination of a few of these? · What is the outcome I want to achieve as a result of this meeting? · Is there an alternative format I can use to achieve the outcome? · If a meeting is essential, what is the ideal meeting format to achieve the meeting outcomes—an in-person meeting, a virtual meeting, or a combination of the two? · Who needs to attend the meeting? · What information do I need from the attendees? · What do the attendees need to know or complete in advance of the meeting to achieve the meeting outcome? · What expectations do I have for the meeting attendees regarding preparation and participation? How will I communicate these expectations? · What is the ideal length of the meeting to accomplish the stated purpose of the meeting? Use the answers to these questions to guide you in planning and preparing for your next meeting.

post_a.text:
The Wharton School  ‘s new Dean  Erika James  talks to  David Gelles   at the New York Times about how she is helping the school refresh its approach to business education. When asked, ‘How do you expect Wharton will change during your tenure?’, Dean James answers, ‘I don’t think we can just assume that because we’re Wharton we can just rest on our laurels and say, we’ll always be safe. We have to be mindful that our competition is not just other business schools. Our competition is complacency, and when you’re the best, it is very easy to become complacent. So one of the things that I hope that my tenure as dean will do is to motivate us to think about how do we want to define business education in the future, and not only rely on what we’ve done in the past. I think the fact that I’m Wharton’s first female dean means there are likely going to be differences in how I engage with our alumni and with our students and with our faculty that are reflective of who I am as a woman at this level in business education. There just aren’t a lot of us.’   #leadership   #education   #businessschools   #MBA

post_a.text:
When it comes to positive behavior change, the issue isn't that we don't know what to do.  Think about this for just a second 👇 You know which foods are healthy and which are unhealthy. You know what goes into maintaining a fulfilling friendship.  You know how to be a good partner.  And if for some reason there's something you don't know? Google is free!  Unlike previous generations of humans, we information is everywhere. The reason we struggle to change our bad habits is that we can't stop getting in our own way. This is why becoming Indistractable is so important... The uncomfortable emotional states of loneliness, anxiety, and stress can push us to make unproductive decisions start from within. The issue isn't that we have innate character flaws, the issue is that most people haven't learned the skills to deal with emotional discomfort in a healthy way!  Until we learn to address the root causes, we'll continue to struggle with distraction.  #Indistractable   #Health   #Change   #Adaptation

post_a.text:
Love them or hate them, Elon Musk and Steve Jobs are known as two of the most brilliant minds the business world has seen.  Yet, despite their ability to process information, think critically, and identify key insights--many of which helped Tesla and Apple reach valuations into the billions of dollars--both men practice(d) an unexpected habit: They embraced the rule of awkward silence. The rule is simple: When faced with a challenging question, instead of answering, you pause and think deeply about how you want to answer.  But make no mistake, this is no short pause. Rather, you might go five, ten, or even fifteen seconds before offering a response.  Which, if you're not used to doing it, will feel very awkward...at first. Want to see some real-life examples of the rule of awkward silence at work? Want to know how this rule can help you: -think more critically; -give deeper, more analytical, more thoughtful answers; -get to root problems more effectively; -develop emotional intelligence? (Read more in today's column.) #leadership   #management   #elonmusk   #stevejobs   #criticalthinking   #apple   #tesla   #EmotionalIntelligence #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

For  #FlashbackFriday , ahead of  #InternationalWomensDay  on Sunday 8th March, I must share this inspiring message from one of my newest  #ScienceSHEroes , one of the first black South African women to earn a PhD in  #ComputerScience . I learn so much from women like Prof.  Mmaki Jantjies (PhD)  of the  University of the Western Cape . I learn that as women our struggles and victories are universal. I was born during America's official apartheid era; Mmaki was born in the country that coined the term. I learn so much about grace and poise and focus when I watch accomplished young women like her achieve their professional goals.  And I feel genuine hope for the future thanks to the contributions of leaders like Mmaki. The way she fights for access to technology for all children in  #SouthAfrica  makes me believe that for decades to come, Mmaki will be inspiring thousands of brilliant young minds. That's why this  #AspenNewVoicesFellow  is a  #ScienceSHEroe . Do you know any others? Write a post about them for Women's Day! If you are a  #watchonista  like me the raging debate is what watch to wear to the  #superbowl  this weekend. I'm going off piste and wearing a  #VacheronConstantin  Historiques American 1921. The origins of this watch go back to 1921, when Vacheron Constantin created a limited series of watches just for American motorists. The idea was to create a watch optimized for reading with your hands on the steering wheel, so the dial was rotated to place it at the correct angle for easy viewing. The high noon numeral "12" is actually 30% off axis and it freaks people out when the see it. This is a new and welcomed addition to my collection modified by the good people at  HODINKEE, Inc.  with a custom red band so I'm giving it some love. I love a watch that starts a conversation!

post_b.text:
One of the most pivotal moments in my indistractable journey doesn’t start with research papers or behavioral psychology or anything like that.  It actually starts with my daughter.  One afternoon, we were doing activities from a book written to help daddies and daughters bond. One exercise consisted of asking each other the following question: “If you could have any superpower, what would it be?”  The second I asked the question, I felt a buzz in my pocket. A work email distracted me from the activity -- and more importantly, my daughter.  To this day, I can’t tell you what she said… While she was telling me her dream superpower, I was busy staring at my phone. By the time I looked up, she had left the room. It was at this moment when I realized that I needed to be better about managing distraction. It was this moment that set me on a five year journey to uncover the roots of distraction and what eventually led me to publishing my second book: Indistractable. If you haven’t had a chance to read the book yet, then you’re in luck -- because I’m giving away ten copies right here on LinkedIn.  All you have to do for a chance to receive one is like this post and tag somebody else to share the indistractable message with 👇

In Other News: A Win For Patients Personal Digital Charts as I call them, or soon to be known as ‘personal digital medical records’ are coming to your smart phone soon! Federal officials on Monday released groundbreaking rules that will let patients download their electronic health records and other health care data onto their smartphones. “Patients should have control of their records, period. Now that’s becoming a reality,” said Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar. “These rules are the start of a new chapter in how patients experience American health care.” Who are the winners? Patients, people and medical providers who want to understand, manage and control their medical and healthcare needs. Who are the losers? Electronic Medical/Health Record (EMR/EHR) companies who want to own your data to make even more money off your pain and suffering. Finally patients will have all the information at their fingertips  to help them make timely decisions —a good first step for all of us.

Gary Vaynerchuk  says it's one of the biggest things to which he attributes his success.  Simon Sinek  believes it's the most important instrument in a leader's toolbox. And  Oprah Winfrey  cites it as fundamental to leadership. The secret of their success is something that might surprise you: EMPATHY. This soft skill is often misunderstood and confused with its cousin, sympathy, which is feeling compassion for somebody.   But empathy is about putting yourself in someone else’s shoes and seeing things from their perspective.   How can YOU be more a more empathetic leader?   First, shift your mindset to put people first. See them as human beings rather than a means to the end of a transaction or task.   Next, ask thoughtful and probing questions that draw out implications and feelings.   Finally, use your awareness to give others your full attention and truly listen to what matters most to them.   When you do these things, you’ll better understand your customers, colleagues, and partners, and then be able to use those insights in ways to better serve and communicate with them.   And in this way, empathy can give you an edge as a leader—and as a human being.   #empathy   #leadership   #business   #success   #relationships   #communication   #growth   #softskills   #career   #HumansFirst   #growthmindset

post_a.text:
One of my biggest pet peeves in communication—especially business communication—is unnecessary complexity.🤦🏼‍♀️ I suggest maximizing the power of your words by simplifying them.💁🏼‍♀️ Communication doesn’t have to be hard; here are four ways to keep it simple: 1️⃣ Aim for clarity over clever🎯 Yes, it’s tempting to be witty in your latest marketing campaign, but if it leaves your audience scratching their heads, you’re in trouble. To avoid confusing people, always aim for clarity. 2️⃣ Avoid unnecessary jargon❌ Swap acronyms and buzzwords for plain language to increase your odds of your message being received—and understood. 3️⃣ Make brevity your friend✂️ When you want to deliver a message, think concise and compelling. Be intentional about your communication, eliminate extraneous material, and get to the point. 4️⃣ Focus on one takeaway🔍 A good rule of thumb is that each piece of content should revolve around one central theme. This forces you to get specific about and home in on your message. And that focus promotes better understanding, making it easier for your audience to understand your perspective. Business and life are complicated enough; keep your communication simple.✅ #communication   #content   #simplicity

post_a.text:
Have you clicked on the Search Appearances feature on your profile? 🤔 You get this notification weekly, some of you ignore it while I suggest taking a deeper look.  On your LinkedIn profile, you’ll see the number of searches you appeared in.  Clicking on them gives you some handy insights. Where it shows the job-titles of the people, this indicates if you reach the right audience. Take a look at whose search you appeared in and see if those are the kinds of searches you want to be showing up in. If the people you are appearing to are unrelated to your field I would recommend seeing if you could make some adjustments to your profile to better align with the searches you want to show up in. As you can see, in my case: 📌People from AppsFlyer search my profile- Hi guys you can reach out to me over slack although I'm more available here😂 📌Most of the people work as SW developers- which is good for me because this is the audience I'm looking to hire. 📌The keywords people search for Sourcer, Recruiter, HR, and Talent are also amazing for me because this is the kind of words I want people to search and find me. So, take a deeper look and try to learn and improve. This is a great QA to your profile. I think a good number should be 300-500 searches🙏🏼 #linkedin   #jobs

Professionals are smart, but are shit content creators. I saying it in the nicest way.  You spent the last third or more of your life: upskilling and developing your knowledge. When someone asks you a question with the problem they are facing.  You respond with passion and with details. But when you go in front of camera... Your personality becomes plain as a white bread.  Your delivery is stiff. Most times you go on tangents. But instead of filming it again and make it better, you tend to give up. The same with writing ✍️  You have a key message. But there’s no style or flow. And maybe you forget to edit and clean up.  The thing about content creation. It’s a skill of communication. It’s something that you need to constantly craft and hone. At the start, you will stumble and fumble. But know that you will get better. I almost failed in English in high school. Look where I am now... I write and create every day.  I have a startup that helps others be a trusted voice on LinkedIn.  Persistence and skills opens: 🍗 opportunities  🍗 confidence  If I can do it, you can too. Need help starting? post_b.text:
Here's something really important to consider about product design: Not all products have to be habit-forming. Life insurance policies don't need to be habit-forming!  What's important to realize is that helping users form a habit is a competitive advantage. This means that when you DON'T build a habit, you have to find a competitive advantage elsewhere.  Some other competitive moats may include: Intellectual property, economies of scale, brand loyalty, or network effects.  But if you don’t have a sustainable competitive advantage, you enter a never-ending fight on price and features. You drop your price, the competition drops theirs.  You add a feature, the competition adds the same feature.  All of these things cut into the bottom line.  This is why habit-formation is so valuable: it’s a sustainable competitive advantage.  #Hooked   #UX   #ProductDesign 
 
 
 …see more

I've worked at companies where annual rewards letters were literally black/white one pagers with nothing more than  "Hello $REPLACEABLE_COG <barf spread sheet>". Seeing my PayPal rewards letter, I am very grateful for the nice template, compensation recap, breakdown, explanation of pay, yearly message from Dan, and thank you from my boss.  A lot of thought and work from actual humans went into the template to make the rewards letter easy for our employees to understand, to provide explanation and resources, and to personalize the message as much as possible with gratitude and empathy.  Words, kindness, empathy and personalization MATTER - especially in a time of virtual work when folks are not personally connected. These are the little things that say "we care". And for that, I'm proud of  PayPal  and the folks that worked on this to make Rewards a great experience for us. Thank you.

I was a salesman snob. Like many people, I always looked down on the concept of “#selling.” It seemed like something lower than me. To some extent, selling appears manipulative.  I was wrong. And for the past 25 years, all I have been doing is selling. Selling products, selling services, selling businesses, selling myself. Sometimes I have been manipulative. And sometimes I’ve sold things I’ve had such passion for that I practically gave them away just to get the message out. And often, it was very much in the middle: I needed to sell something because I had to pay my bills. I wanted to make sure my family got fed. But I can say that over the past 25 years, I’ve sold hundreds of millions of dollars of stuff. post_b.text:
To reap  #career  and  #leadership   #success , think like a farmer:   Prepare the soil.   Make a conscious effort to create a safe place for others to flourish. Model vulnerability, lead with empathy, actively listen, and encourage open communication, to foster trust and collaboration. Adopt a growth mindset allowing your curiosity to fuel lifelong learning.   Intentionally plant seeds.   Having clarity on what you want is key to achieving it. Maintaining focus will help you and your team do the things necessary to expand your experience and skill sets. Align your attention and intention to plant the seeds for continued growth.   Let the seeds grow.   Empower your people to make their own decisions—even if they differ from yours. Step back yet offer your support and resources to allow others to thrive. And practice self-compassion by not pushing yourself to achieve goals in impossible timelines.   Remove any weeds.   A toxic employee, unreliable partner, or over-demanding client can take its toll if left unchecked. Same goes for outdated processes, services, or activities that drain your precious resources. Proactively assess the fields of your career and pull the weeds early and quickly.   Learn from previous harvests.   To thrive, view failures as learning opportunities.

post_b.text:
Are you feeling stuck, figuratively and literally?   With the mandated shelter-in-place orders enacted for our collective safety, it’s hard not to be frustrated and antsy, especially if you’re someone who thrives on making progress.   Though it might sound counterintuitive, sometimes, the best way to move forward is to go backward; here’s how:   First, take time to reflect Before the coronavirus crisis, you likely felt over-programmed and overworked with no time to think. Now is the perfect time to harness the power of the pause and take a break. To maximize this period, slow down and carve out time in your calendar for quiet reflection.    Next, refocus your efforts After you’ve reflected, record, and review your thoughts to see if any common themes emerge. Now’s the time to refocus your efforts on looking for new opportunities that align your skillset or offering with current demand.    Finally, re-engage by taking action Once you’ve had time to reflect and refocus your efforts, create and execute a plan. Taking action is the antidote to fear, doubt, and anxiety—and stagnation. In these trying times, re-engaging by taking action helps move you closer to your goals, which spurs you on; action begets more action.    #career   #progress   #coronavirus 
 
 
 …see more

post_b.text:
So, with the Cosby verdict, truth has finally emerged. I have been wondering if part of the problem is that many people saw Cosby as Dr. Huxtable, an example of conflating truth and fiction.  Ironically, both fellows dispensed meds -- only one was a doctor and not a real one at that.   We often confuse truth and fiction.  I think this is something as to which we can all fall prey --- not rape, goodness knows.  I mean we can mistake truth and fiction. We want to believe fictions -- they are often easier than truths.  We even enhance fiction sadly.  Just look at the Michigan State debacle.  Truth was buried.  We don't want heroes or doctors or presidents for that matter to fall -- so we psychologically distort truth.  Human flaw.  And now, the victims can see that truth does eventually show its face. Brava for their strength over all these years.  Fiction just got its comeuppance. #psychology #fiction #victims #truth

post_a.text:
President Trump is scheduled to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday to discuss a possible resolution to their ongoing trade war. One factor that could be pushing the president toward a deal: His trade policies are broadly unpopular with American voters. A new survey conducted for  The New York Times  by  SurveyMonkey  finds that a majority of Americans think the trade fight with China will be bad for the United States. There's a big partisan split -- Democrats and independents oppose the tariffs by a wide margin, while Republicans overwhelmingly support the president's approach. But even most Republicans think the trade war will raise prices. Will any of this matter in 2020? Hard to say. Trade doesn't generally rank high on voters' lists of top issues. It hardly even came up at the first Democratic presidential debate. But if the trade war starts to damage the broader American economy, then all bets are off. For more, check out my story in the Times. #china   #economy   #tradewar   #trade  #2020

Last year I met  Gary Vaynerchuk . My legs were shaking before I grabbed the mic for Q&A (I don't get nervous for anyone 😂). To keep it short, basically I quickly told my story, thanked him, and went up on stage to give him a hug. I was creating a data point in that moment. A point in time where our stories intertwined. I've thought a lot about influence the past few years. I gave a talk on it a few weeks ago. The reason why my legs were shaking and the reason why that hug met so much is this:  I can go back and pinpoint the moment where Gary impacted my life. I was in the weight room, in college, and my triple jump coach told me to check out a guy named "GaryVee." And from there I went down the rabbit hole of entrepreneurship and content. Failed with two companies but found a lot of success with the third. Gary is impacting others & creating those data points at scale for other people.  I was supposed to give a talk on monetizing your personal brand... I talked about impact instead. Because the 💰will come if the impact is there. #justQ  🖖🏾🖤  #business   #entrepreneurship

Animals Share the Same Emotions As Humans...Or is it that Humans Share the Same Emotions as Animals. I’ve heard it said from anthropologists, scientists, biologists, geneticists and researchers that in fact animal emotions are the purest form of emotion. Why? Because they are not burdened by the “inner voice” humans have which distort the raw emotion with self-doubt, and rationalization. Think about that the next time you look into your pets eyes! Selected Excerpt: “Uniquely human emotions don’t exist. More and more, I believe that we share all emotions with other species in the same way that we share virtually every organ in our bodies with them. No exceptions.”

Want to build your personal brand? Personal branding is a marketing technique that allows you to stand out from the crowd. It's all about being memorable.  On a personal level, it's you walking in your values every day. Integrity and trust are key ingredients to a reliable brand. On a business level, it allows people to recognise your value and think - yeah, I like this person and they can help me solve my problem. They trust you to guide them to the best solution. If you're creating content, you want it to align with your brand.  Another thinking is to be a brand-creator. You intentionally create effective content that showcases: 🍗 Your personality 🍗 Your credibility 🍗 Your experience  🍗 Your knowledge  This allows you to attract an audience and build a community. And yes, find clients. Ready to level up your personal branding for 2020? Drop into the comments: 🍗 or fried chicken. If you're vegetarian, drop your fave fruit emoji instead. Bonus points if you share your favourite flavour.  #stringsecret  to  #personalbranding #stringtheory   #stringstory   #linkedinmarketing   #contentmarketing   #contentcreation

post_b.text:
To say Elon Musk has a lot on his plate is a huge understatement. Of course, running a company the size of Tesla is plenty challenging. But Musk is also CEO of space exploration company SpaceX, which has a stated mission of taking humans to Mars and "other destinations in the solar system." And that's not all. Musk has also founded or currently plays major roles in a number of other companies. So, how does Musk do it? How does he manage his time, so he can keep his finger on the pulse of so many things? Musk revealed a very simple yet effective productivity hack in an interview some years ago: He splits his time so that he can basically focus on one company at a time. Of course, few of us are trying to run multiple companies as Musk is, nor do we have access to a private jet. But I've found great value in separating different aspects of my work by days of the week.  The key is not to try to do as much as Musk does in a week. Instead, decide what your priorities are and then adapt accordingly. (Read more in today's column.) #leadership   #management   #productivity   #elonmusk   #tesla   #spacex   #EmotionalIntelligence #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

Despite the upbeat news on the vaccines, I think we are struggling mightily across the nation with three key issues: (1) Pandemic fatigue including Zoom fatigue; (2) Absence of interpersonal touch and connectivity; and (3) Upcoming holidays and "tradition" changes that distance us.  In a sense, the second "surge" feels, at least to some of us, worse than the first surge; the numbers are perilously high; we have a dysfunctional transition of power (whatever your political persuasion) that is harming our nation. Some of us have become more isolated than perhaps even necessary due to fear as others flaunt mandates and best practices.   In a sense, we are unaccustomed and unprepared for what is happening in our nation.  We can rightly ask: how do we move forward with grace and wisdom and perspective?  What compensatory mechanisms can we deploy to help all those who need help? And, what about our children and their ability to navigate forward?   I have one thought: I have hope.  I still believe despite some evidence to the contrary that people are decent and caring and at the end of the day, the better side of humanity and the wiser voices will rise to the top and be seen and heard.  I still have hope.   Do you?

post_b.text:
Let's talk DATA! I have exciting data about the industry, 3-months post corona. I will give my insights. The basis for the information is from  AdviceMe.Il   so of course, you can not generalize it to all populations. Nevertheless it's interesting. First - the average age of people who asked for our advice: 26-33. I can explain it mostly by experience, 26-33 usually are employees at the beginning of their careers, and companies prefer to keep the seniors because they're more expensive to hire and of course, more valuable. Second, 1 out of 5 people is a software developer! Well, I was amazed by this one. I would think that SW people who are in high demand would be the last to get fired. I can explain it with 2 ideas - first, most of them are juniors /from small startups that had to close, second, AdviceMe's branding was especially oriented for tech people. Another interesting piece of data- 80% of the people who asked for our advice had at least an undergrad degree. The higher education was the fewer people there were. I guess companies won't let go so fast of people with high education. Also, 90% of people with 3rd degree had a managerial experience which is not a surprise. I want to thank  Or Hazbani   for all his help and great insights. And, 3 months later, I'm back in the office!

The real story about on-boarding from home🏡 It's a difficult thing to on-board in a new place, getting to know your teammates, managers, the company culture, unwritten rules, and more. And now, we need to do all of that online- boom!💥 Yes, it's hard and the main thing everyone is focused on is the relationships and I understand.  Relationships are the baseline for everything and yet we tend to forget a very important thing- Workplace politics!🔵🔴 Its difficult to understand from zoom meetings and this is our job as teammates to explain to the new people on our team. ✔️The history of the team (don't disrespect, this is important!), projects, fliers and wins.  ✔️Relationships with other teams ✔️Social relationships between teammates  This is crucial information, and when you on-board via zoom you don't always manage to get it. Did I miss something? comment and let me know what do you think. #HR   #workpkacepolitics   #onboarding   #people

I recently started the Imani Arts Foundation - a nonprofit organization providing free resources and support for youth in the entertainment space. We had our first fundraising event on May 6, 2018, and raised over $1500 dollars! A special thank you to poet Arielle Estoria, the McCreay Foundation gospel choir, and the Clavillo sisters for their awesome performances. The Imani Arts Foundation is driven by a fundamental belief in the innate power of guided creativity. Studies show that young people who have high creative potential have increased self awareness and as a result, often struggle in the area of personal identity development. Guided creative achievement, on the other hand, leads to an increase in personal growth. Our organization is designed to provide the tools and access necessary to help youth of all backgrounds and socioeconomic status discover, develop, and deliver their creative gifts in a safe space. post_b.text:
For #ThrowbackThursday, 5 days in #Somaliland. Soaking up the privilege of observing a master at work: photojournalist  Lynsey Addario  capturing images for our  National Geographic  project on #maternalmortality. Having Lynsey teach me a cool iPhone photo filter trick on the night before she left was amazing enough. But then, on the way home from dinner that night, riding shotgun with Madame  Edna Adan Ismail  in her trusty Tata 4-wheel drive, the living legend who built herself a hospital In Hargeisa began to sing. "Though we ain't got a barrel of money...." I chimed in, "Maybe we're ragged and funny.....” "But we're traveling along, singing a song, side by side." In a moment like this, you suspect you must've done something right in your life to earn such a transcendent experience. You realize that no matter how many curves life has thrown you, or how many challenges may lie ahead, you are #blessedandhighlyfavored.  #natgeotraveller #amomenttoremember #globalhealth

post_b.text:
Many of us are in what could only be described as a liminal space in our careers. We’re literally in between what was and what’s next for us, career-wise. On the verge of transformation. And we don’t like it. We hate the wait and not knowing, but lasting change rarely happens fast.  Though it seems counterintuitive, embracing the pauses of liminality can be the best way to fuel your career growth. “Liminal thinking” is a way to create change by understanding, shaping, and reframing our beliefs. The idea behind it is that there are doors of opportunity all around us, but we fail to see them because we’re focusing on other things. When we use it to tune into these incredible potentials for growth and change, we’ll see things that others miss or can’t imagine. To get started, take stock of your current beliefs—which ones are holding you back? And how do these limiting beliefs spill over into how you view others and move through the world?  Next, learn to let go of the old to make way for the new. Create an environment that is open to differing views and welcomes new ideas. Expand your horizons by exposing yourself to fresh thinking and activities. When you adopt a new way of seeing the world—and yourself—you open the doors to change and growth. #leadership   #career   #liminality 
 
 
 …see more

post_b.text:
Attention, leaders: Have you lost your voice?   As a professional communicator, I rely on my voice as a tool. It helps me articulate my offering, communicate with and connect me to others, and supports my values and perspective.   Of course, “voice” extends to all forms of communication, whether spoken or written and collectively makes up your personal brand.   Ideally, you have a consistent voice, no matter the medium. This is especially true when you’re trying to build your brand and your reputation as a thought leader.   Consider then, for a moment, if maybe you’ve lost your voice…   ► Do you struggle with having and maintaining a clear point of view in your communications? ► Does the subject matter of your content vary dramatically, causing folks to scratch their heads? ► When someone meets you in person, are they surprised because you somehow seem different?   These are all red flags that you may be losing your voice—and your ability to communicate effectively.   Regularly sharing your unique point of view in those few areas where you have expertise will position you as an expert, eliminate confusion, differentiate you from your competitors, and draw others—employees, clients, partners, and investors—to you.   #leadership   #communication 
 
 
 …see more

post_a.text:
What if you applied the same consistency and discipline to carving out time just to “be” rather than to “do?” Research shows breaks are essential to improving our moods, overall well-being and performance capacity. It also suggests that creativity depends on something most of us are hesitant to do: daydream.  This may be why insights tend to happen when we’re not focused on our problems, but rather, when we’re doing something unrelated, like taking a shower or walking with our dog. But for those insights to occur, they need room to appear. And that can only happen when you give yourself the time and space to think, feel, and experience; here’s how: Conduct a time and activity audit Most of us move mindlessly through our days, putting out fires and responding to requests rather than carving out time to do the deep work of thinking that can help propel us forward.  Schedule—and keep—regular appointments with yourself Take back your time by blocking out non-negotiable “appointments” with yourself where you’re free to let your mind wander, imagine, and process.  Realize that time spent “being” is as essential as “doing” Giving yourself the time and space to think, feel, and experience is complementary, not contradictory to your career progress. #career   #leadership 
 
 
 …see more

I never had that Father figure growing up. And I’m not saying that to be down, I’ve just never had that. As kids we looked out for one another. We did what we had to do to survive.  And for that I appreciate my dad. His absence taught us how to take care of ourselves. How to make shit happen on our own. How to survive. And I’m thankful for that. Because while we are building our new company, some days I feel like I’m on top of the world. Some days I feel like I’m about to be laid out by a bus. Some days it feels like I was laid out by a bus. But it’s a survivor's game. And I’ve been playing it my entire life.  #justQ  🖖🏽🖤 📸  Willie Morris

If someone hits the "like" button on your content that doesn't mean they are a part of your community. It means they liked your content. That's it. You have to work to get them in your community. You have to give them a reason to be in your community. A like is just a like. A community is a part of the journey. Who are some epic community builders that you follow? post_b.text:
Once again Liz Ryan hits on a key idea that holds so many of us back from creating careers that we truly enjoy - fear. I totally agree that "your career is a business just as surely as any multinational corporation is. It is your ship to steer -- but only if you know how much power you possess!" Ryan said the first step in finding work that will make use of your talents, personality and passion - and offer you more than a paycheck - is to give yourself permission to dream again.  I'd take that a step further and suggest that you dream big. With planning, hardworking and skillful/thoughtful use of the abundant resources that are available to coach and teach us how to create more fulfilling businesses and careers - baring unforeseen life-related circumstances - the only real thing keeping us stuck is personal choice. Remember, fear is just false evidence appearing real. Try. It's far better than not trying. Regret, I find, is a grotty, horrible thing.

It gained 1.7% today compared to 0.6% for the S&P and 0.1% for the Dow ... increasing what already is considerable out-performace. As detailed in prior tweets and last on CNBC on Wednesday, this should not comes as a huge surprise. It's consistent with actual/forward-looking attributes ("edge") of many virtual-space oriented companies, and most of Big Tech.  These attributes are a big plus in both the economic lockdown (journey) and in the post crisis world (destination). #markets   #stocks   #nasdaq   #dow   #investing   #investors   #investmentmanagement

post_a.text:
I’m drawn to that special place where magic happens… …at the intersection of art and science. …of attention and intention. …at the cross-pollination of industries, backgrounds, experience, and ideas. …where two (or more) seemingly disparate things come together.  Because I know that from that spectacular collision and union, fantastical new concepts are born. Never before imagined things. Things that change people and companies and the world for good.  And I want to help motivate and encourage others to visit that place. Often. I want every interaction with me — whether it’s reading my writing or meeting face-to-face —to leave people feeling better about themselves, and life in general. Simon Sinek  (and  Wendy Weiner Runge ) would call it my “why,” or my reason for being, but it boils down to this: inspiring transformation. Every day I look for ways to help others communicate and connect to effect positive change. I live for what’s possible, for myself and others.  That’s where I want to be.  Where I strive to be.  Won’t you join me? #transformation   #change   #communication   #connection   #innovation   #creativity

post_a.text:
Psychologists tell us that loneliness is as detrimental to our health as smoking or obesity. It is crucial to our mental and physical health that we maintain meaningful relationships with the people we care about.  But how can we have healthy relationships if we’re always on our devices, scrolling through our newsfeeds, and responding to an endless stream of external triggers? There is no compromise here. We must be fully present with the people we care about.  This is exactly why I consider the ability to manage distractions the skill of the century.  All of us must make a choice: Will we allow our attention to be manipulated by outside factors or will become indistractable and in control of our own lives?  #Indistractable   #Control   #Relationships   #Health   #Longevity   #Productivity

You hear a lot today about the need for authenticity. BUT... What does it truly mean to be authentic? Authentic people share their true thoughts and feelings with others. It doesn’t mean sharing everything about yourself, with everyone, all of the time. It does mean saying what you mean, meaning what you say, and sticking to your values and principles above all else. Authentic people know not everyone will agree with them, and they realize this is okay. They also understand that they aren’t perfect, but they’re willing to show those imperfections because they know everyone else has them, too. By "keeping it real," and accepting others for who they are, authentic individuals prove relatable. The result when you're truly authentic? Not everyone will appreciate you.  But the ones who matter will. Read more about how to build trust in my new book, "EQ Applied: The Real-World Guide to Emotional Intelligence":  https://amzn.to/2sxFLho   #EmotionalIntelligence   #leadership   #management   #PersonalDevelopment   #BestAdvice   #business   #careers   #BusinessIntelligence   #EQ   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

Google made waves recently by announcing its new program, "Google Career Certificates," a collection of courses designed to help participants get qualifications in high-paying, high-growth job fields without attending university. I think this move is a step in the right direction--a separate path for students who are looking for something different than traditional higher education. And it's coming at a time when it's needed most: a time when a global pandemic has thrust millions out of jobs. A time where skills-based training is in great demand.  In the U.S., education is an industry, one that's been dominated by the same legacy players for far too long.  And as in any industry, options are a good thing. Competition is a good thing. Because out of competition comes innovation. Out of innovation comes disruption. And out of disruption comes progress. So, for those who have held up progress for far too long, consider yourselves warned: Disruption has arrived. Change is coming. (Read more in today's column.) #google   #virtuallearning   #virtualclassroom   #virtualeducation   #management   #leadership   #eqapplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

(SDR backing would have been neat but i suspect it would have been too difficult from start) - Libra needs on/off ramp access to financial system to thrive, so expect those partners that left to work on a partnership behind the scenes. - would not be surprised to see large banks among the 180 eligible partners, but they will wait & are where the winds blow - Libra to clarify privacy & data usage/management. - Libra to become more of a payment system & less “crypto voodoo” to appeal to regs & govts.   #currencies   #tokens   #Libra   #payments   #USD   #fintech   #Facebook

post_b.text:
When I wrote my first book, I wasn’t doing many speaking engagements.   It was easier for me to write because I didn’t have so many demands on my time. But the more popular the book became, the more distracted I got, flitting from one thing to the next, always checking my device.   When I sat down to write or work on other projects, I would check emails or the news, just to distract myself. Because at the time, I didn’t have the right techniques in place.   Learning how to manage my time and attention, turned into a project that eventually became my second book: Indistractable!   I didn't write the book because I had superhuman self-control. I wrote it because I didn't.   And one of the important things I realized was that learning to control my attention didn't just help me finish my work on time. It helped me in my relationships with my wife and daughter. It helped me align my schedule with my values.   For anybody still looking for holiday gift ideas, I'd recommend the gift of becoming indistractable. I've included a link in the comments section to some signed copies of my book my publisher is selling.   How are you spending the holiday season with your loved ones?    #Indistractable   #Author   #Gift   #Holidays   #Focus

post_a.text:
I was asked my top five tips on  #personalbranding : 1. Brands matter.  We live in a world of options and commoditization. Whether you’re an individual or a corporation, your brand is what distinguishes you from all other lookalike options, and defines your place in the world.  2. A brand is a promise.  Branding goes deeper than colors, font, logos, or a headshot. It’s a promise you make to the world; this is the kind of experience you will have with me.  Live up to that promise, consistently. 3. Perception is reality.  Marketing, at its core, is about changing perception. Building a personal brand is about being thoughtful about the perception the world has about you.  Use it to get you where you want to go, not to satisfy your ego. Clarify your end-game. 4. Ask for three words. If you’re stuck defining yourself in a pithy way (it’s not easy) ask friends and colleagues to describe you in three words.  Look for patterns.  5. Be yourself. Don’t try to be the person you think you should be. Have confidence in what you bring to the table. Your best brand strengths come from what differentiates you.  If you're in Boston, join us Thurs night at Shopify for a panel event and workshop on this topic aimed at entrepreneurs! (Link in comments.)

post_b.text:
You’re only one decision away from a totally different life. Making a positive, life-changing decision requires three steps for success: 1. Awareness When we’re unhappy, it can often feel like there’s no way out, but you always have options. The first step in making a  #choice  is the  #awareness  that you have one. At this stage, it’s not about editing yourself on what’s possible; it’s about being mindful that change starts with you and your attitude. (Note: choosing not to make a change is also a choice; if you’re not changing it, you’re choosing it.) 2. Attention with Intention Once you’ve realized that change is an internal job, consider those things within your control and how they impact—for better or worse—what you want. Bring your  #attention  to your  #intention , and ask yourself what’s the one thing you can do right now to bring you closer to your  #goals . This need not be a grandiose, sweeping gesture; the biggest change starts with a small step in a new direction. 3. Action This last step may seem obvious, but far too often, we fail to act even when we know that making a change is in our best interest. Nothing changes if nothing changes. And action begets more action, giving us the much-needed momentum to keep going, no matter how slowly we start. #leadership   #career

Assuming Dr. Ford testifies, I want to know how we can get people on the Judiciary Committee and in the Senate truly to listen. Could we put our R/D affiliation in a drawer and just listen and hear?  If the point of a hearing is to hear, then prejudging and announcing one's vote ahead of time or that Judge Kavanaugh will be appointed misses the point of a hearing. And why plow ahead?  We plow fields not people. I get the rush but do we do justice by rushing to find truth? One more thought:  Youthful indiscretion is not rare. What is bad here is: failure to own one's past; failure to apologize; lying. The Justices decide about real people; truth matters.  Truly matters.  So does integrity.  So does honesty.  Judge Kavanaugh is not being criminally charged (too late); but he bears burden of persuasion.  This isn't about innocent until proven guilty in a criminal trial. There is no trial. There is a hearing on fitness and integrity. Worth distinguishing and remembering. 
 
 
 …see more

post_b.text:
Distraction is dangerous.  Perception mistakes caused by healthcare practitioners while working in hospitals, injure hundreds of thousands of Americans annually.  A group of nurses at the  University of California, San Francisco  wanted to figure out why this was happening.  Here’s what they found 👇 The reason people were being given the wrong medication was because nurses were distracted.  Seriously!  When nurses were dosing out medication for patients, they were interrupted, on average, ten times per dosing round.  These constant interruptions were the source of avoidable mistakes.  So, how did they address this?  They didn’t need to spend millions on a new program or technology. Nurses wore cheap plastic vests that read, “drug round in progress. Do not disturb.”  Mistakes dropped by 88%. Whether it’s finishing a project for work or dosing out life-saving medicine, we cannot do our best work when we’re constantly being interrupted.  Do you sometimes feel like a nurse constantly interrupted and distracted? How do you block out distractions? Any other stories like this that come to mind?  #Indistractable   #ProblemSolving   #Productivity   #Health 
 
 
 …see more

post_a.text:
I have just found the perfect quote to share with all my fellow  LinkedIn  sisters for #WomensHistoryMonth.  It's from the sublime actress Tracee Ellis Ross, who was sharing her journey with body image and other life issues with People Magazine. “You know as a young girl, I had this woman that I dreamt of being, right? And I had her in my head and I would play around with being her in my bedroom and with certain people, but the gift of age is that you actually get to have the boldness and the courage to be that woman, to be that person and I’m experiencing it now and some of the things I’ve discovered in knowing myself is that I actually like myself,” she said. After reading her comments, it clicked. THIS is what it means to be a fully grown, proud, brave, confident woman.  And I knew this former little girl who used to sit on the levee wall looking out over the Ohio River in Cairo, Illinois and dream about amazing adventures and making a difference in the world really is the woman she always dreamed she could be. Thank you, Tracee Ellis Ross, for reminding us that while it's important to honor our foremothers this month, we must always celebrate our own history.

post_b.text:
Not all doors on an escape route will be Fire doors and not all Fire doors will be Escape Doors. So I've seen a few posts and conversations recently regarding Fire Door Inspections, Fire risk assessments etc. The conversations seem to revolve around whether a inspection should include all doors or only designated fire doors and should they have and follow a FRA. Maybe a few people are missing the point and maybe missing an opportunity. For example the last door to escape the building is not likely to be Fire Door because it doesn't form part of a compartment. Does that mean the Inspector would leave if out of their scope? If a door is on an escape route but isn't necessarily a FD30 or FD60 should it still be inspected against BSEN179 and/or BSEN1125? yes it should. so maybe there are a number of doors in a building that aren't necessarily Fire doors but do form part of an escape route and are integral to life safety, yet the discussions seem to be about just the Fire doors.  If you or your company would like to expand their knowledge and possibly increase revenue talk to Abloy UK or sign up for the Abloy Foundation course here:  https://lnkd.in/dRwMXdT #Abloy   #doorsets   #firedoors   #firesafety   #doors   #lifesafety   #fire   #locks

Me? I love it and giggle at the thought of how many healthcare providers and hospital systems will be annoyed because 'these companies are trying to practice medicine.' And, incidentally might migrate patients away from them.... But that's NOT why I love it--I love this because healthcare insiders won't change and the change must come from outsiders...and Lord knows, we need change--if it's an improvement ... because we all know that not all change is an improvement , but all improvement requires change!

I thought I would be prepared to handle the blow of Ms. Cicely Tyson’s passing. After all, 96 years is a good long run of elegance, talent, grace, beauty and passion.  I guess all I really wanted was a chance to personally thank her for making me feel like I could be beautiful, smart and adventurous even as a poor Black girl from Cairo, Illinois.  When I first saw the movie “Sounder,” I saw myself in the character Rebecca Morgan. And though the poverty and struggle was there, I also saw the dignity and strength and determination.  So thank you,  #CicelyTyson , for helping me see the hero within myself as a young girl. Along with my foremothers, you laid the foundation for the woman I am today. #RIPCicelyTyson   #Hollywood   #BlackActors   #AfricanAmericans   #AfricanAmericanHistory   #legends   #legendsneverdie   #BlackActresses   #Acting

They are her responsibility at work and she is going to continue take care of them at home.   #ownyourjob   5) While working from his home office bed (his wife got the downstairs and the kids- I think he got the better deal) our CTO took time to  work thru a complex analogy on data science for an article I’m working on.  This was after crazy long hours working thru regular CTO issues in this new world. 4)My Radical content partner is moving at the speed of light to help produce our new LinkedIn Live show where our content has to be fresh and timely. 3) Our customers are chill with the tax extensions and being digital (we do proactive tax planning and they are even asking about possible retro tax cuts! We have trained them well!) Other CPA firms in our building have not had similar responses. Continued below----- #gratitude   #cpa   #newworld   #radicalcpa   #cpafirm   #ai   #bots

DON’T SAY “I DON’T HAVE TIME.” SAY, “IT’S NOT A PRIORITY.” This is more accurate language, says Fast Company writer Laura Vanderkam, author of I Know How She Does It. “I could tell you I don’t have time to train for a marathon, but that is not true; I just don’t want to! Using this language reminds me that time is a choice. If I’m not happy about the way I’m spending my time, I probably have the ability to change it,” asserts Vanderkam. Think about where you need to start being honest with yourself and your priorities. Everything cannot be a priority. The sooner you admit this, the easier it becomes to focus on your real priorities.

Speakers on tonight's panel were  Mary Gallivan, MBA , VP and Director of the Centers for Giving at the  Foundation For The Carolinas , Kelly Brooks of  SHARE Charlotte ,  Josh Jacobson, CFRE , Managing Director of Next Stage Consulting, and Michael DeVaul, Chief Community Impact officer for the YMCA of Charlotte. The FOMO of Clubhouse got to me. Everywhere I see, on my Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, it was "Clubhouse, Clubhouse..." I went on to my Twitter and asked for an invite, within 30mins I was browsing the clubs, rooms, and hallways.  Lurking and Listening.  I even got kicked out of the room. I didn't know what I did wrong haha, I think I got heat from loving fried chicken 😂. 🏠 Clubhouse is likely going to the hot trend of the year. Just like TikTok was hot, you be hearing more about the platform. The advantage of being an early adopter: 🍗 Access to influencers and decision-makers  They are obsessively hanging and sharing high-value knowledge.  I listened to Lupe Fiasco moderated a chat about anti-capitalism.  Millionaires are hanging here?!  Great for entrepreneurial-minded people who want to see what the mindset is like. 🍗 Networking w. high-value folks 🍗 Create a channel / build a community  The key is to moderation and being a great host.  But what I really love (and agree with James Andrews), the voice of diversity is lit. The variety of colour is what makes me happy. People of colour are dominant here.  Who else is on Clubhouse, though on it so far? My handle is @stringstory - let's connect on CH  #stringtheory  on  #social   #clubhouse   #digitalmarketingtrends

post_a.text:
Love him or hate him, you can't deny the success of New England Patriots star quarterback Tom Brady. Despite being way past his prime and one of the NFL's oldest players (now at 41 years old), Brady just secured a starting spot in his ninth Super Bowl. That's not only the most appearances by any single player... It's more than any other NFL *franchise.* In his postgame press conference, Brady was like a kid in a candy store, barely able to hold his excitement. "How do you do it?" Reporters wanted to know. "How do you manage to stay so calm in the biggest moments?" Brady's reply: "One play at a time." Whether you make a crushing mistake or do something great, these five little words can make all the difference in the world. (Read more in today's column.) #EmotionalIntelligence   #leadership   #BestAdvice   #management   #culture   #PersonalDevelopment   #BusinessIntelligence   #careers   #TomBrady   #Patriots   #Superbowl   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

Long story short: we grew quickly, failed a lot, learned a lot, and our team was crushing it pre-Covid.  So coming to terms with the fact that it’s all coming to an end has been difficult for me to deal with because a lot of energy, sweat, tears, and hair loss (lol) went into that business.  I’m not the type of person that dwells on things. I never really have been. But this has been hard for me to shake (hence my three month absence from writing these).  I guess the beautiful thing is that I haven’t been sitting idle. I’ve just been quiet on social media. I’ve been thinking a lot about brand, what I want to do next, and who I want to be next. It's good to be back. I missed y'all. #justQ  🖖🏾🖤

post_b.text:
Are you struggling to be heard? Your natural inclination may be to raise your voice, literally or metaphorically. But this world has a cacophony of noise. Tons of distractions. A million reasons that make it difficult to listen. Yelling louder won’t help you break through. Worse, you’ll be another person/brand/company “screaming” at others. Instead, consider doing something completely counterintuitive: whisper. Or don’t speak at all; use non-verbal forms of communication. Because doing so may provide you with a point of difference. And because you stand out, you’ll get attention. The right kind of attention. And when you have that, you can finally deliver your message and be heard. Remember, communication isn’t about being the loudest in the room. It’s about connecting with your intended audience. Respectfully, kindly, creatively. And I, for one, would much rather connect with someone who cares enough not to yell at me. ‪ #leadership   #career   #communication   #connection ‬

post_a.text:
❌Manager ≠ Leader❌  A manager controls elements to achieve a specific goal.  A leader influences, motivates, and enables others to contribute toward organizational success.  What makes an excellent manager won’t help those who aspire to lead in making that transition; these will:  1️⃣ Relinquish your need for control There’s a reason they call it “micromanaging” and not “microleading.” Leaders are secure enough in themselves that they empower others. They hire the smartest and most talented people and then get out of their way.  2️⃣ Put people before processes (and yourself) Leaders understand that at its core, business is powered by people, so they shift their focus to put others first and help them feel seen and heard. They also invite and align them around a shared vision, inspiring and motivating them to be their best. 3️⃣ Model leadership behavior Leaders don’t become leaders from a title bestowed upon them; they model it through their behavior by intentionally embracing their  #softskills  and  #emotionalintelligence . Leaders who proactively do the hard work to “walk the talk” earn credibility, naturally attract others who look to them for advice and wisdom and understand how to bring out the best in themselves and their teams. #leadership   #career   #IlluminateMe

post_b.text:
When I first heard that schoolgirls in Western  #Kenya  were being required to undergo mandatory tests for female genital mutilation and pregnancy, I was reminded once again why my voice does not belong only to me. It belongs to women and girls everywhere, because so many of them have no say in what happens to them. I lived in Kenya for 8 years, so Kenyan schoolgirls aren't just exotic concepts to me. The fact that so many who've survived the incredible trauma of  #FGM  and sexual abuse will be forced to endure these invasive, humiliating examinations just breaks my heart. I acknowledge the stated attempt to measure the scope of the problems. But why isn't there more effort to investigate and humiliate the people who torture and exploit these young girls? Why aren't there stricter laws to punish people who support and perform FGM, and who rape young girls? Why do  #womenandgirls  always have to bear the brunt of the shame and ostracism that flows from the violence committed against them? While I have a voice, I'll keep asking these questions. UN Women   Girls Not Brides: The Global Partnership to End Child Marriage #EndFGM   #genderbasedviolence   #EndGBV   #HearMeToo   #OrangeTheWorld   #reproductivehealth   #reproductivejustice 
 
 
 …see more
post_b.author: Rachel Jones

post_a.text:
I haven’t always lived with personal integrity... I’d promise to eat right, then I'd find myself scarfing down fast food.  I’d promise myself that I’d exercise regularly, then I'd stop going to the gym.  I’d promise to finish up that big project, and it didn't always happen.  I operated mostly with a to-do list.  I listed out my tasks, but they wouldn't get done. The items on my list would always just move to the next day, I’d never accomplish everything I set out to do. It was a horrible feeling.  The problem is not that we don’t know what to do. Any of us can pull out our phones, search Google, and find answers for how to lose weight, live healthily, or be more productive at work. The problem is that we don’t know how to stop getting distracted. Have you managed your time and attention more effectively lately? #Indistractable   #Accomplishment   #Values 
 
 
 …see more

post_a.text:
So I wanted to share several things -- seemingly different but related.  The Cookery in Shirlington (Arlington) VA is having an event June 1 starting at noon in their remarkable cooking/food store for International Children's Day. And, they will be making a donation to Save the Children. I will be doing a book reading and signing at this event -- with two of my newest children's books. There will be food, fun and activities. One of the goals is to enable children to appreciate the fun that can come from engaged reading and the books are meant to achieve that.  Also, given the starvation and deaths of children across the globe, it is worth pausing and reflecting on what we can do to improve the lives of the next generation -- near and far. There is homelessness and food scarcity in many areas -- hidden and not so hidden poverty and a deep inequality for children in education too. That gets me to my next point: I will be at Molly Stark School in VT (which is I believe close to 100% free and reduced lunch) on June 3 to read and work with children.  I will be sharing one of the new books and helping kids appreciate the value of words and reading.  And, it is key to curb summer melt causing low income kids to fall behind while their wealthier peers progress ahead.   Come join us.

"Toxic." That's the Oxford Dictionary's 2018 word of the year.  Runners-up include "techlash" and, sadly, "gaslighting." Yikes. Each fall, Oxford selects a word that they believe reflects “the ethos, mood or preoccupations” of a particular year.  It's downright depressing to think that "toxic" sums up how we felt about 2018.  What if 2019 was the year our "ethos, mood or preoccupations" at work and in our communities shifted to words like: *collaboration *trust *innovation *diversity *empowerment *equality *inclusion *respect I can dream, right? And you can too. What word would you add to that list?

Don’t We All Want To Be a VIP? VIPs get the best of everything—whether it’s the best table at a restaurant, or best seats at a ball game.  And when it comes to healthcare, VIPs get the best treatment, doctors, therapies and monitoring. ‘VIP-ness’ is a feature of American medicine.  Major hospitals throughout the country have private spaces for celebrities, the super-rich and the influential. These VIPs get the most vigorous care and therapies . . . even when there isn’t enough medicine—or even hospital beds—for the rest of us ‘regular Americans.’ In my days caring for patients, every one of them wanted desperately to be treated as a VIP. Everyone wants the best medicine and best doctors, nurses and therapies. Everyone.  Selected Excerpt:  “We know that VIPs get extraordinary care — our health-care system already distinguishes between people deemed worthy of the highest level of care, versus those deemed unworthy. And that is the fact and the reality in our society.”

post_b.text:
One of the techniques to avoid distraction during tedious tasks is to reimagine them.  Commercially produced distractions, like television or social media, use slot machine-like variable rewards to keep us engaged with a constant stream of newness.  But we can use the same techniques to make any task more pleasurable and compelling. We can use the same neural hardwiring that keeps us hooked to media to keep us engaged in an otherwise unpleasant task. Given what we know about our propensity for distraction when we’re uncomfortable, reimagining difficult work as fun could prove incredibly empowering. Imagine how powerful you’d feel if you were able to transform the hard, focused work you have to do into something that felt like play. Fun and play don’t have to make us feel good per se; rather they can be used as tools to keep us focused. Instead of running away from our pain or using rewards like prizes and treats to help motivate us, the idea is to pay such close attention that you find new challenges you didn’t see before. Those new challenges provide the novelty to engage our attention and maintain focus when tempted by distraction. #Indistractable   #Productivity   #Empowerment   #Engagement   #Traction 
 
 
 …see more

Casey Foundation  and the  Mecklenburg County  Youth and Family Services Division.  I’ve been reporting and writing about  #socialpolicy  affecting children and families for the past 3 decades, and unfortunately, I’ve produced far too many stories about tragedies and incompetence and mismanagement. $1.5 Billion Skilling Australians Fund to be Established The {Australian} Government will establish a new Skilling Australians Fund to ensure that businesses that benefit from employing skilled migrants are also equipping Australians with the skills they need.  Employers that sponsor migrants under the new temporary skill shortage visa and certain permanent skilled visas will be required to pay a levy which will provide revenue to the Fund. Through the Skilling Australians Fund, an estimated $1.5 billion will be provided over the first four years to underpin a new partnership with State and Territory Governments to train Australians, with spending prioritised towards apprenticeships and traineeships. The Fund, when matched with State and Territory funding, will support up to 300,000 apprentices, trainees, pre-apprentices and higher level skilled Australians. Source: Extract from the Australian Budget 2017-18 Janine McPhee   Andrew Sezonov   Mark Mallia   Nathan Ellery

Firings forced me to look at my life situation, take a bigger picture than I was taking, and figure out the new slices of life I can now taste. Being rejected is an invitation to sample more from life. And having a checklist helped me ignore all the bad chemicals that were trying to bring me down. #Madoff forced me to look at my life with a bigger lens. I started new businesses. I channeled my frustration into more networking, into ideas, into experimenting with my creativity to try new careers. I do the items on this checklist almost every day. Thank you Bernie Madoff. You did very bad things. And I met you when I was lost in my life. This is not about you. Or about me. It's what you and I did together. Here they are... 10 things you need to do if you were #fired yesterday:  http://ow.ly/YhRN30iRjU6

post_b.text:
"Sorry mate, I can't promote your condom" A company approached me and asked me to promote his condom business. I replied back - "it doesn't align with my branding, but I appreciate the offer". Here's the thing - if he was familiar or follow my content, he would know that I like fried chicken and I'm a geek. -- When it comes to personal branding, it's definitely about integrity and aligning your values with your brand. A good brand has a strong trust factor.  To build trust online, it's not hard, it's about creating consistent content that reinforces your positioning. One of the reasons why I been able to gain roles as a brand creator is that I understand how and where I fit in the world, and what value I can bring to the table.  I made many mistakes in the last 4 years but I learnt a lot. Which inspired me to re-consider about how I can help coaches and experts build their brand. One that enables higher accountability and action. Each month we focus on creating outcomes. In the 2nd chapter of the playbook, we break down what marketing assets you required to build a consistent brand. From:  🍗 your brand story 🍗 updating your socials with consistent branding 🍗 leveraging LinkedIn and more Interested? See the link below #stringtheory  on  #personalbranding

post_b.text:
i read a newsletter where the author discusses how $10mm was recently transferred between two ethereum addresses for 7 cents & took seconds.  author rightly points to all the inefficiencies of bank transfers. also rightly points to the fact that in crypto there is no “recourse” if a mistake is made or fraud happens. BUT wrongly concludes that *banking without banks > banking with banks*. more appropriate would be *banking without banks ≠ banking with banks*  given the risk profiles are vastly different. further your own risk aversion profile may make you a bank user name or a crypto/defi user.  above tx cost 7 cents vs maybe max $30 in US (tad lower in EU). but it could have cost the entire amount had there been a mistake or fraud whereas the bank w/its $30 cost gives you peace of mind.    #fasterpayments   #crypto   #ethereum   #banking   #banks   #defi   #blockchain   #cryptocurrency   #cryptocurrencies

post_b.text:
Culture Eats Consumerism for Lunch   While ‘Consumerism’ is all the range in healthcare, moving beyond the slogans to the real-world of strategy development and implementation—and measurement—is still in its infancy. Why? Even though many technologies are mature enough to demonstrate real value, getting people within organizations to change from their old ways is hard. The biggest challenges to innovation is not the technical aspect of intraoperability or, realizing a return on investment, but rather on the necessary adoption, implementation and change management that goes hand-in-glove with innovation.   I do a lot of change management so I consider myself to be an “Organizational Culturalist.” As an Organizational Culturalist, I function like a medical anthropologist helping  organizations develop and implement technology adoption roadmaps.   If ‘culture’ is the biggest barrier, then it’s time to think of culture like anthropologists rather than technologists.   Selected Excerpt:    "Everybody thinks the only way you can innovate is to have some technological advance," he said. "We're finding a lot of innovations can occur without the use of technology but with changing the team and changing the thinking."

post_b.text:
I LOVE love. Even more than I love money! A life partner if the biggest, most beautiful, & most LIFE changing investment you'll ever make. Choose wrong, game over. Choose right, & you get a life of fulfillment that even the most stacked savings account can't offer - and if you're really smart, you'll have both! . I watched my mother's marriage to my father collapse when I was young, so I learned the risks of love and romance at an early age. But I watched her forge a successful partnership with my stepdad George, which gave me hope... Still, I had no idea that in my late 20s I would meet the woman who would become my wife.  Linda and I have been married almost 30 years now, and I still marvel that she possesses all the skills and traits I lack. She's kind & patient where I can be a jerk, serious when I'm a joker, firm when I was a pushover with the kids. Without her, I'd never have achieved the things I have. Throughout my climb in business, she kept the home fires burning while I dug the coal to keep them lit. Linda & I dated for six years before we got married. By the time we finally tied the knot, we weren't starry-eyed kids rushing down the aisle...but we knew we wanted a future together.  Happy Valentine's Day, kiddies! 
 
 
 …see more

post_b.text:
I started speaking a little under a year and a half ago. 🎤 😬 And it’s been a journey figuring out everything: my style, how many speaking engagements are too many, how much time do I need to prep, should I prep, and so on. There are no rules for this stuff. I finished TEDx two months ago and it was 7 months of prep. I just did Disrupt Madison and I prepped for maybe a total of 5 hours over time. And I knew what I wanted to say... and then for the first time I walked on stage and everything went blank. I forgot everything that I wanted to say. So I winged it. And it went fine. But I hate not being THE BEST. And I’m really working to find my balance. On camera I don’t really prep. On the stage (personally) I’m learning that the more prep the better. Preparation is the best weapon. Kind of like when I was a musician. You play a song so much that it’s burned into your memory. You can go off script and still come back to the song because it’s become muscle memory. People have taken flights/driven from other cities/countries to come see me speak. And I feel an obligation to be the best. To make it worth it every time. Otherwise, what’s the point of speaking at all?  From here on everything that I do, will be the best of me. #justQ  🖖🏽🖤 
 
 
 …see more

post_a.text:
Morehouse College Honorary Degree Recipient Robert F. Smith did an extraordinary thing: he announced that he and his family would pay the debt of every graduate.  He said he was part of the Class of 2019 and they all needed to start the next phase on a level field.  Wow! How remarkable, especially given that there was apparently no knowledge ahead of time that Mr. (now Doctor) would make that promise. What a gift. What an act of grace. What a way of paying it forward. And Mr. Smith wasn’t  a Morehouse alum! Forget how high the bar is for honorary degree recipients moving forward.  Forget the feelings of relief so many there experienced. Don’t forget that Morehouse is an HBCU that has struggled financially.  Don’t forget the powerful message of belief in graduates and their promising future as leaders. If I had a magic wand or billions of dollars (I don’t), I would repay the debt of every 2019 graduate of a college that is closing this year. Talk about a remarkable end. I understand the “last” Southern Vermont College graduation this weekend was moving and forward looking. I’m glad the event was so memorable. Now, here’s my other hope: that this will not be SVC’s last Commencement because other donors will see the value of small colleges.  That would be a remarkable gift. 
 
 
 …see more

post_a.text:
I was invited to join a group in Milwaukee — black & brown leaders pushing for change. I said something in the group last week that went like this:   I’m not sure if this will make sense, but this is how I think. Imagine a funnel. Like a sales or content funnel. You have top of the funnel, middle, bottom. Awareness all the way down to the conversion (or sale).    Everything that is going on right now is top of the funnel. Protests, riots, videos sharing/showing experiences, etc. It’s bringing awareness to the problems that we are having. To the problems that have been there.   A question that I would pose to the group is this… what does our funnel look like to bring about change?    How do we convert? What is in the middle of the funnel? What is at the end? Because just like a business would never solely succeed from top of the funnel... lasting change will never happen if we only focus on the top of the funnel.   Just something to think about.   #justQ  🖖🏽🖤  #diversity   #blm 
 
 
 …see more
