My Hong Kong-based colleague  Kevin Sneader  was interviewed by the FT recently about his plans to reshape McKinsey once he takes the helm as our next global managing partner.  “From July 1 he will be in charge of the world’s biggest partnership—a sprawling business with 2,000 partners and 28,000 staff across 65 countries that has registered breakneck growth over the past decade, doubling revenues to $10bn.” “His first big shift has been to overhaul McKinsey’s leadership team to ensure a better gender and geographical balance. The new team of 15 McKinsey partners includes five women whereas previously it had one.  It is also less heavily skewed towards partners from the Western Hemisphere, and includes the heads of six regions: Europe, Latin America, China, Asia ex-China, North America, and Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa. This is the first time China has been treated as a stand-alone region—a strong indication of where Mr. Sneader sees growth potential for the firm.” (Registration required/paywall) #McKinsey #consulting #China

It was my “first day” yesterday at my new gig.  I’ve been around for a while but did the whole HR thing and was given logins for all the new internal technologies. It was a day filled with meetings and new things.  In between I sat in an open office near a young professional with couple years of big firm experience,  on his day two.  We got to briefly chat.  We went to dinner with the larger team.  When we were saying our goodbyes, he said “You’re going to sit by me tomorrow, right?!”   Absolutely, my new friend!    I’m sure he doesn’t know how special and comfortable he made me feel.   It doesn’t matter if you are 25 or almost 50......change, new expectations and transitions are exciting and unnerving.   And it’s Awesome to have a new friend saving you a seat for tomorrow.  #theperfectendtoafirstday   #radicalcpa     #cpafirm #cpa   #hr   #culture   #firstday   #newjob   #people   #accounting   #techstartup

If you've applied to a job or considered just reaching out to people who inspire you and wish to work with them, take notes of Daniyal. His approach was genuine, personable, and memorable. post_b.text:
Are you an emotionally intelligent leader?   Here are three ways you might not have as much EQ as you think (and what to do instead):   1. You pride yourself on speaking your mind. While candor in the workplace can be valuable, not every thought should be voiced immediately (or maybe, ever), especially in an emotionally-charged situation.   Instead: Press the pause button. Emotionally intelligent people understand the power of taking a beat to digest and consider information before responding to it.    2. You treat every employee you manage the same. You're trying to be fair, so you employ the same management methods with every member of your team, regardless of their needs, and expect them to conform.   Instead: Move away from a one-size-fits-all mentality. People are individuals, with unique needs. Take the time to learn about what your direct reports need, and then adapt your style to serve them.   3. You're "coin-operated." Being "coin-operated" means you're motivated by money—and little else.   Instead: Find motivation in the challenge. When you believe passionately in your products and services, you're motivated to help find and provide solutions and value to your customers.   #leadership   #EQ   #emotionalintelligence   #career   #softskills 
 
 
 …see more

post_b.text:
Unless you want to burn out, you need to learn an essential  #leadership  lesson: protect your  #time . Here's how:   Establish  #boundaries Maintaining a healthy balance by making it clear that you'll respond to work messages during business hours and within a day.   Learn to say no Become more discerning with your time. Saying no to the people and things that don't support your goals will give you more time to say yes to those that do.   Empower your team Trust the smart folks you've hired to do their jobs without you and keep you in the loop, freeing you up to focus on what matters most.    Resist the urge to multi-task Multi-tasking destroys  #clarity , which is essential for  #productivity . When you're working, be singularly focused on it; when you're not, be fully present in your non-work activity.   Eliminate distractions Turn off notifications, click out of tabs, put your phone on airplane mode, close your door or use noise-canceling headphones. Do whatever it takes to help you focus on the matter at hand.   Work with your body's natural rhythms Block out your peak for your most important work and save mundane tasks for later.    Carve out non-negotiable time for what matters most Replenish yourself with whatever (or whomever) fills your tank, and make that time non-negotiable. 
 
 
 …see more

post_a.text:
You really need to read this information from  UNICEF  about who has access to safe, clean  #water  and  #sanitation  - and the shocking number of people worldwide who still don’t. Tremendous progress has been made in recent decades, but more than a billion people in the world still don’t live near a safe water source. They still don’t have access to a toilet, which means they’re still vulnerable to diseases related to poor hygiene like diarrhea, schistosomiasis and trachoma. Every time I swallow a sip of cool, clean water, I remember those who would give anything to have it. Every time I shower, I think of all the babies and children who would joyfully splash around in the water raining down on me, and appreciate being able to enjoy it without getting violently ill. We must stop taking these things for granted, and collectively work to ensure that more people have access to safe, clean water. Via  Forbes #globalhealth   #globalhealth   #watersanitationandhygiene   #WASH   #waterscarcity   #watersupply   #diseasesofpoverty   #toilets

It’s a convenient excuse given that we love to blame others. The tech itself alone is not responsible for our tech overuse. Some of the responsibility falls on our shoulders as well. I’ve found that there are mainly two types of people when it comes to tech overuse: - A Blamer, someone who assigns the blame to iPhones, email, the “modern world,” etc. - A Shamer, someone who shames themself for their own lack of control The right approach is to be a Claimer, someone who acknowledges that we didn’t necessarily invent any of these distractions, but that the responsibility still falls on us to use them well. I had a conversation with  David Pakman, MBA  about this topic and how to fend off “learned helplessness” on The David Pakman Show. Check out the full clip at the link in the comments below! After watching, share some steps you’ve taken in an effort to take responsibility for your distractions. #Indistractable   #TheDavidPakmanShow   #HumanBehavior   #Tech

This is an insightful article on how people promotions impact company culture and performance. The onus is on a company to make its promotions’ process well-defined and transparent. When employees are clear about how decisions are made on promotions, they know what is expected of them, and where their company is headed. Otherwise, employees are demoralised, and engage in unproductive guesswork, which helps nobody. All companies claim to have their own ‘culture’, but surveys show it is often superficial, and not ingrained amongst the employees. Also, criteria for promotions in one company may not work for another. It’s the guiding philosophy of the leadership team which determines the ‘culture’ of a company.  Michael C. Bush   Jessica Cross Rohman  #companyculture https://lnkd.in/fzyKaBF

post_a.text:
I was just scrolling through the  Apple  iPhone Shortcuts app and saw they had one for saving a song for later called "Add to Queue" which made me pause. It is interesting to see how everyone now just accepts that the 'queue' means adding media to a list because that wasn't always the case. Back in the early days at  Netflix , no one was using it that way. And while it didn't really line up with the definition or common usage of the word in English, it was unique and considered to be an "ownable" brand asset here in the United States. Again, "ownable" meaning no one here was using it in that way. Because no one was using it that way we had to constantly educate prospective members as to what the Queue was. And there were always discussions about changing it. But any company could have a "movie list" so it remained in use.  As the company grew over the years, so too did the adoption of that use of the word. Competitors and even non-movie related companies used it to mean the same thing.  Which is how we arrived at having that be the default for "add media to a list." Of course, since Netflix has become a global streaming service, they've moved to "My List" but the effects of using Queue as a brand asset appear to be rather long-lasting. #apple   #netflix   #queue   #brandassets   #brand 
 
 
 …see more

post_a.text:
It all started so well. 🍝 I eagerly loaded my place with luscious strings of goodness, topping them with a delectable meatball set in a pool of red sauce. All that stood between me and my pasta was the three feet between the stove and the dinner table. But in that longest yard, something terrible happened. It turned out freshly cooked noodles weren’t just delicious; they were wet. And wet spaghetti was slippery. You know those paper towels commercials where a kid unexpectedly spills something, and everything starts to move in slo-mo as their eyes widen with fear?😱 Yeah, that’s what I looked like as I clutched my plate and watched my dinner slide right off it and on to the floor. Not once. Not twice. But three times. (Yes, really.) No matter how carefully I reloaded, it was déjà vu all over again.🤦🏼‍♀️ The “spaghetti incident” (as it’s known in my family) was a teachable moment (and no, not about how awkward teenagers and slippery dinners don’t go together). It’s easy to fall into this trap in your  #career  too. You become stuck in old habits or mindlessly go do the same things over and over again, expecting a different result.🤪 If you got my latest  #IlluminateMe  newsletter, you’d know what to do instead. Find the link in the comments below.⤵️ #leadership

post_a.text:
“Personally I'm always ready to learn, although I do not always like being taught.” Winston Churchill   Take for example the ‘new thing’ we’ve all had to learn about face coverings: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says "everyone should wear a cloth face cover when they have to go out in public" to help slow the spread of the Corona Virus.  Mind you almost 70,000 Americans have died of this disease so far.   And yet, some people just don’t want to learn.  The response in the city of Stillwater Oklahoma which is requiring citizens to wear face coverings (like so many other states),  threatened store employees with physical violence and showered with verbal abuse.  Learning and ‘being taught’ new things is at the core of advancement—or ourselves and for our country. And to my way of thinking, learning new things is foundational to the American Experience and what makes this country unique among others.   So, when did American Exceptionalism turn into ignoring science, fact and honoring The Self over Others?    Here’s what I learned as a child that was hard-taught but that still works today: ‘Be kind and considerate of others, and don’t be a selfish idiot,’ and you will be loved by your family, friends, co-workers and neighbors.   Why is that hard to learn? 
 
 
 …see more

post_b.text:
YOU DON'T NEED THE JOB TO BE HAPPY! Depression is highest in fully employed, first world countries. The two highest countries for depression? France and the United States. We simply were not made to work 60 hours a week. Archaeologists figure that our paleo ancestors "worked" maybe 12 hours a week. Why is work depressing? Not all of these reasons but maybe some of them. ➞ Being bossed around by people we don't respect. ➞ Being forced to be friends just because they share our cubicle walls ➞ Meetings ➞ Seeing the 80/20 rule in action where 20% of the employees create 80% of the value and the other 80% just barely survive. ➞ Being mandated by an 800 page guidebook how you can talk to people of the opposite sex or of different skin colors. ➞ Seeing corporate political agendas rule over financial realities and not being able to say anything about it for fear of being fired. ➞ Spending 6am to 7pm getting ready for work, commuting to work, working, commuting back, too tired to move when you return home. #Jobs are not so great. And they cause a lot of suffering. And you don't really need them. Bear with me... http://bit.ly/2m32LTb

When a colleague comes by and asks whether you have a minute to discuss a project, you might respond, “Right now, I don’t have time, but we can talk tomorrow at 10:00 a.m., when I’ll be able to be fully present and able to focus on the project.” You can also redirect your colleague by suggesting that someone else might be able to help them.

'Putting  #people  first' is the key to lead  #transformation  at an organizational level.  Jim Hemerling  shares five building blocks to navigate transformation. -  #Inspire  through purpose: Lego's purpose is to 'Inspire and develop the builders of tomorrow' by enabling more children to experience joy to play and imagine - Go all in: Rather than cutting costs, focus on initiatives that drive growth and actions that fundamentally change the way the company operates, Invest to develop leadership and talent.  - Enabling people with skills and tools to achieve  #success  energises them and takes away overwhelming anxiousness caused by change. - Instilling a culture of continuous learning: Shifting from fixed performance mindset to growth mindset - listen, learn and bring out best in people - While being directive, leaders also need be inclusive. Leaders need vision, roadmap and milestones, and hold people accountable. But also listen to and implement ideas coming from the team.

post_b.text:
One time, my daughter and I were doing a Daddy-Daughter interview activity. My question to her was, “If you could have any superpower, what superpower would you want?” I wish I could tell you what my daughter said, but I was distracted and on my device, doing some unrelated task. I regret having blown this great chance to bond with my daughter. Every self-help book I found told me that technology was the problem and I did everything I could to counter this, even getting rid of my iPhone.  It didn’t work, as I found that getting a flip phone and a 90s word processor to type weren’t preventing me from getting distracted. Through research and experience I learned that distraction starts… from within. Watch and share your thoughts! 👇👇👇 #Indistractable   #Technology P.S. If you pre-order Indistractable, I'll send you the PDF version of the book NOW, months in advance of its release! Just fill out the offer form at the link in the comments (N. America only).

Building your personal brand is power... Yes, power. It attracts:  🍗 customers and clients  🍗 community (who wants to work with you) 🍗 audience (who wants to consume your knowledge) And control. It allows you: 🍗 build your own business 🍗 Or a side hustle while working in a 9-5 job 🍗 Or land you that job you want  Building a brand allows you to stand out. An important part of branding is understanding your niche market.  For example, anyone can be a coach. But what's your speciality? What results would you bring?  Why should they come to you? What industry do you want to position yourself? For example, Sales is a super broad horizontal. What's your special thing, your niche, your vertical? B2B Saas? Mega Enterprise Deals? Be specific.  Being too broad also dilutes your brand.  So how does fried chicken relate to all this? Well, when you eat a piece of 🍗, you think of me. Then you think, "OMG, String is so good at marketing".  #stringtheory  on  #personalbranding   #b2b   #motivation   #digitalmarketing

Last Thursday evening, Amazon released this year's first quarter results. Unsurprisingly, it revealed that Amazon's one of the few companies thriving in the midst of the Covid-19 pandemic. Along with those results, though, came a lengthy statement from CEO Jeff Bezos. In it, Bezos outlined details regarding his company's strategy in the face of what he described as "the hardest time we've ever faced." Bezos went on to outline the company's strategy for the next quarter. There's a lot to break down in this statement, but let's begin with just four words: "These aren't normal circumstances." This statement may seem simple, but it actually teaches a major lesson in emotional intelligence. (Read more in today's column.) #Amazon   #leadership   #management   #coronavirus   #COVID19   #EmotionalIntelligence #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

post_a.text:
When you’re  #perceptive , you’re good at understanding and figuring things out. Perceptive people are insightful, intelligent, and able to see what others cannot. They envision the possibilities, embracing what could be, rather than being satisfied with the status quo of what is.   They use the  #softskills  of  #listening  to make them sensitive and responsive to their team’s needs;  #awareness  of others to fuel their ability to truly “see” people beyond the façade of their armored shells and then ask probing questions to understand better what matters most to them; and  #empathy  because they know the power of understanding their audience is paramount to business success.   These leaders realize that it’s not about them, and know that to  #communicate  and  #connect , they must put other people’s needs first.   Positive leaders tend to have a growth  #mindset  or one in which they believe they can—and will—improve, and see every opportunity as a chance to grow and learn.   They’re  #curious  and tolerant of new ideas and people and are less like to be thrown off course because of an unexpected setback. They empower others to make decisions. And their openness builds  #trust  naturally, which allows them to connect with others more easily.   #leadership   #positivity   #emotionalintelligence

post_a.text:
🎉WHOA, I had a blast with you all, guns blazin' and donuts glazin'!🍩 In a world filled with stress, noise, and crisis, it would be easy to believe that real social connection has lost its magic... But that couldn't be further from the truth! And this group proved that last night. We sold out in a few days (even though the tickets were free) and we had a couple of tech hiccups... 1) Waiting Room  We discovered that when we are ALL in breakout rooms, there isn't anyone left hanging around to admit those in the waiting room... so if you showed up 10 min late, that's my fault - we hope you can join us next time, on time 😉 2) Host Overwhelm The host has to admit people, present/speak, AND control breakout room assignments. It's best to have multiple HOSTS if you can! The introvert in me is loving this social distancing, but I have missed your smiling faces and cannot wait to catch up next time! If you're eager to learn about more LinkedIn Virtual events, comment "Count me in!" and I'll tag you as soon as we share the next eventbrite link or add you to the even here... Thank you all for spending some time with me! #Connection   #Community   #LinkedInLocal

Fun fact: Just because a company is bigger, doesn't mean it will win. Case in point -  Walmart . That's right, circa 2005 Walmart decided it wanted in on the DVD-by-mail space and launched a competitor to  Netflix .  It's reasonable to think that a bigger company with more resources might be able to outpace a smaller startup. But for Walmart (their online division ran this) it was one of many initiatives. For us, DVDs-by-mail was all we did. And despite all the tongue-wagging at-launch about how they were going kill Netflix, Walmart ultimately folded up shop.  By the way, this image is a scan of their envelope which was absolutely copied from Netflix.  #netflix   #netflixhistory   #walmart   #DVDs

But it doesn't matter if it was a good year or a bad year. It was just a year. Now we have to move forward and figure it out. That is what it means to be an entrepreneur. Not posting videos on LinkedIn or Instagram. Not bringing a bunch of unpaid interns to make it look like you have a big team. Not giving a bunch of advice on something you haven’t done anything yet. In an anecdote about a large investment bank, a partner called a meeting for new graduates at 5pm, only to turn up at 10. The lesson was about patience in the client service business...'to wait patiently for those who are more important than you'.  I have done my fair share of waiting for clients. I have also done so with family and friends, but eventually brought it up with them and come up to an acceptable agreement. How do you feel about punctuality? post_a.text:
Not All Hospitals Are Created Equally.Not By A Long-Shot. This article highlights a very sad story of a poorly run pediatric heart program at a highly prestigious children’s hospital. Many of the problems at this hospital are similar to problems found at other hospitals that have specialized programs, including perhaps the biggest issue: not treating enough patients per year (or case volume) to develop the needed medical expertise to reliably get safe patient outcomes. Reaching adequate case volumes to keep up skills is a challenge because so many hospitals are competing for patients — these programs are an important driver of profits, so hospitals want to keep them going. Some geographic regions (and many countries) have creative ‘regional hubs’ so that an area could only have as many cardiovascular surgical programs as the population could support...Unlike what we see in this country where competing programs might only be a few miles apart. What to do? Look up publicly reported data (Hospital Compare is a good source), ask doctors for their complication rates and ask how they compare to other, top-notch programs... Selected Excerpt: “When you get on an airplane, you want a pilot who does this every day. By having a dedicated (medical) team, you reduce variability.”

post_a.text:
Antarctica contains about 90% of the world’s ice and around 70% of the planet’s fresh water; both are vulnerable to warming air and waters. The protection of the Southern Ocean is a defining issue for our time, and it can help bring countries together. Protecting large Antarctic marine areas will boost ocean protection by an order of magnitude greater than anything achieved before. We now have a once-in-a-generation chance to do things differently and protect more than 7 million km2 of the Southern Ocean by 2020. To create the largest act of ocean protection in the history of the world, we need everyone’s help to reach one million petition signatures. Please join us and sign the petition at  only.one/antarctica . Antarctica and all of the creatures that live there need us more than ever.

Jack Dorsey and Mark Zuckerberg were asked whether social media is "addictive" by Senator Lindsey Graham today.  Their answers were both correct but will also be widely misconstrued and misunderstood.  Social media, like any other analgesic, is potentially addictive, but only to a small portion of the population, as is the case with alcohol and compulsive gambling.  Addiction is more complex than just the product being abused and requires smart legislation to help people struggling with the pathology of addiction. Addiction is not the same thing as distraction.  We need "use and abuse" policies to identify and help people suffering from addiction while leaving moderate users alone. https://lnkd.in/dsDBAmM https://lnkd.in/dKywX-n #socialmedia   #indistractable   #productdesign   #mentalhealth

post_a.text:
Here's a lesson for leadership in a time of crisis:  When things go wrong, a leader needs to own the wrongs that have occurred.  It's easy to cast blame on others who held power in the past. But anyone holding a leadership position for more than a year or two has to take responsibility for current messes/mistakes. And, new leaders, this is hard and I know from experience and my own errors: you can only blame your predecessor and institutional bad acts for so long.  Once one gets the lay of the land, a leader owns the institution's past. Ownership is key to trustworthiness, the ability to live with oneself and to take real action.  Blame gets you nowhere. Why do I raise this now? With all the institutions struggling with one crisis or another, particularly in education, we can see the value of being forthright.  Stand up and own what went/is wrong. And, then take the steps needed to remedy the situation. Think Georgetown owning its slave past. Remarkable. Think Penn State not owning its silence. Troubling.  And, by the by, PR folks would agree: It's best for institutions moving forward if their leaders step forward.  Remember the President of Columbia who climbed out his office window to avoid student protesters? As they say in the law, res ipsa.  #presidency   #leadership   #crises 
 
 
 …see more

I started my esports podcast late last year with no expectations. A few months later and I've had thousands of downloads, conversations with owners of teams, invited to events, played with pro players, etc. Just because I wanted to start something that interests me. Two platforms that I'm spending significantly more time on: Twitch & TikTok. Just because I get to spend more time doing things that interest me. Talking about esports, my business, video games, and life as I live it.  People have this idea in their head that they need to create "content" and that content needs to look/feel/sound a certain way. And it doesn't.  You can do whatever you want to do. And you'll find that when you're doing what you want, you'll also attract the opportunities that you want. Just like my podcast. Just like everything I post here. Make sure it's something you want to be creating. Not just something that might get you views, likes, shares, or wins in the short-term. Just something to think about. #justQ  🖖🏽🖤

post_b.text:
There are two kinds of work: “reactive” work and “reflective” work.  Reactive work is addressing the pings, rings, and dings. It’s attending meetings, responding to emails, and taking phone calls.  Most people’s days are filled to the brim with reactive work. It demands their attention and makes people feel productive. But we also need time for reflective work.  Reflective work is where the problem-solving and creative work get done. It's where we make plans for the future and it has to happen without interruption.  If you don’t make time to work without distraction, you are letting distraction trick you into prioritizing the urgent at the expense of the important.  When none of the important reflective work gets done, opportunities are missed. We must make time to think or we’ll go through our days mindlessly. How are you going to make time for reflective work in your day?  #Indistractable   #Reflection   #ProblemSolving   #Leadership

post_b.text:
What does the future of education look like to you? David Rogier: I still think online education is in its infancy. There are different phases: Phase 1: Simply put information on the web (e.g. Wikipedia) Phase 2: Put the classroom on the web (e.g. Khan Academy, edX). Phase 3: Education designed for the internet (e.g. MasterClass Codecademy). We are still early in this phase — actually designing classes for the web. When Phase 1 made information easily accessible, the role of education became not the transfer of facts (which many classes still rely on) — but to inspire you to go learn, to go do, to geek out. To do this, you have to have engaging and exclusive content, world-class storytelling, and simply amazing classes. Phase 4: “Online education” won’t exist. It’ll just be “education.” We’ll see almost seamless integration between physical and digital worlds. To quote Mark Twain: “I have never let my schooling interfere with my education.” Phase 5: Matrix style. You’ll download Samuel L Jackson’s brain into yours. https://lnkd.in/gQkrNMW   #founder   #entrepreneur   #onlinelearning   #education   #innovation

post_a.text:
If someone offered you $200K, would you use that as seed capital for your startup or use that to pay for an MBA at Harvard?  I believe that there is no right or wrong answer to this and it totally depends on a person's current situation and long-term goals. There pros and cons to both options.  1. Starting a company is like jumping off a cliff and assembling a plane on the way down, according to Reid Hoffman. I agree with his analogy. Starting up is hard and too many wrong moves in a row can lead to a crash landing. But many well-executed moves and your startup can soar and succeed. Some people are ok with ambiguity and can thrive in these high risk, high reward environments. 2. Getting an MBA can be compared to spending time sharpening an axe before going to cut a tree. An MBA can help you get a theoretical understanding of business concepts and how to approach situations. But the proof of the pudding is still in execution.  What would you recommend?   #HigherEducation  (MBA) vs  #startups ?

post_a.text:
A “tell” is a behavior that reveals someone’s true thoughts, intentions, or emotions inadvertently. The ability to read these signs can be a powerful  #communication  advantage in your  #career ; here’s how: 1. Watch for non-verbal cues Customers with crossed arms as you’re pitching a new concept to them probably aren’t open to it. But if they maintain eye contact, lean slightly toward you, or mirror your body language, they like what you’re saying. 2. Listen for incongruence Ever had a conversation where someone said one thing, but the way they said it seemed off? Or what someone says doesn’t jive with their body language? Notice conflicting cues. 3. Read between the lines If you and your client have relaxed, conversational email exchanges that suddenly become more formal, it could be a signal that your project has gone off the rails. Have a live conversation to get a handle on what’s happening. 4. Pay attention When you pay  #attention , you establish a baseline of verbal and non-verbal behaviors. When they deviate from the norm, you’ll be tipped off when something isn’t quite what it seems and have time to investigate. 5. Trust your gut Don’t underestimate your gut instinct. If your intuition is telling you something is off, there’s a good chance that it is.  #leadership 
 
 
 …see more

post_b.text:
I’d like to clear something up about behavior change and creating healthy habits: the issue is NOT that we don’t know what to do!  We all know which foods are good for us, which exercises to do, and how to maintain healthy relationships. And in the off-chance that you don’t know how to do something, there are endless resources that could answer any question you may have.  The issue isn’t that there’s a lack of information. The issue is that we can’t stop getting in our own way. And this is exactly why becoming Indistractable is the skill of the century 💡 Because in order to understand the leading cause of distraction, we have to look within. The uncomfortable emotional states of boredom, loneliness, uncertainty, anxiety, and stress can push us to make unproductive decisions.  These uncomfortable emotions aren't character flaws or moral failings. They're completely natural and we all experience them. The issue is that most people haven't learned the skills to deal with emotional discomfort in a healthy way.  Until we learn to address the root causes, we'll continue to struggle with distraction -- whether it’s at work, with our families, or with our personal goals.  #Indistractable   #Health   #Emotions   #Decisions 
 
 
 …see more

Hey kids, we're one week in to 2019 and I've got one more resolution that you can still add. I'm sure you can guess what it is. PAY. DOWN. YOUR. DEBT. That is without a doubt the most important thing you can do for your future Of course you want health and happiness, and everybody wants everybody to have that, but in terms of taking care of your family and you, paying down your debt is No. 1. If you want to find financial freedom, you need to retire all debt — and yes that includes your mortgage.  Craft a plan to speed up principal payments on your debt, whether that be on your mortgage, a student loan debt or credit card debt. If you have mountains of different kinds of debt, tackle your credit card debt first, because that’s typically the debt with the highest interest rates.  Look at your credit card and you say to it, ‘I’m paying off your balance buddy, and I’m going to do that before July.'

post_a.text:
For  #FlashbackFriday : Me with some of the brave young reporters of the  Voice of America  "South Sudan in Focus" reporting team, May 2015.  Bonifacio Taban ,  Hannington A. Ochan ,  Santino Manut  and  Waakhe Wudu  were among a team of reporters who taught me what courage and commitment really mean. I flew in and out of Juba,  #SouthSudan  a half dozen times during my one year contract with VOA, but I mostly edited and managed schedules from a desk in Nairobi.   During those tense moments when you wait for a check-in call from a journalist who's been detained by government officials, or when the generator has failed just moments before deadline, or when sickness or an accident threatens a reporter's life, you wonder where they get the grit work under such unstable, dangerous conditions. And then you remember:  they love their homeland. They have a passion for truth and justice, and they want everyone to live in peace and security. So even though the pay is scant or non-existent, even when they're demonized and scorned, young men like these epitomize the core of what makes journalism so vital to the concept of democracy.  I salute them and all of my journalism colleagues worldwide. #Africa   #journalism   #globaldevelopment   #media   #capacitybuilding

They sold the story of perception. It's cool to drink an icy cola drink. I'm a baby chick compared to them. My journey started 10 years ago!  Still, they are a corporation and I'm a person who appreciates the value of a creative and sustainable brand. I built my "String" brand of being a geek from the future, who adores fried chicken.  I did it all by myself. I wish I didn't.  What if I had guidance? Would I fast track my growth? Still, I created a playbook. I like systems and results.  In 2020, I plan to focus and help amplify brand creators. I love to see more epic and meaningful conversations.  I'm hungry to meet volks who want to make a difference. I recorded 500+ videos before anyone really watched, this is what I've learned when it comes to sharing your story. 👇🏽 And real talk, there isn't a special formula. At the end of the day, anything can work but you have to find what works best for you. I would say regardless of who you are start with 👇🏽  1). Finding clarity. Take time to get to know yourself and hone your voice. Brittany Krystle preaches this. If you don't know YOU and why people should follow you, then more than likely they won't. 2). SAM LISTER talks about how if you're unsure of the direction and what stories to share, then a good place to start is by documenting. This is the route that I took initially as well and it helped me achieve step number 1. 3). What's your overarching story? Why are you doing this? Where are you going? A good single story will get people to watch, but a good overarching story will keep people coming back for more. Those are a few things that I've learned. What would you add? #justQ  🖖🏽🖤  #SamIAm  ✌  #Marketing

post_b.text:
Have you ever left a job only to find after a short “honeymoon” phase in your new job that you’re right back where you were in your previous job?? We all have fallen into the “grass is always greener” trap at some point in our careers and/or life.   Do you ever think there must be a better way? A better way to work and to experience work without suffering or quitting?   The short answer is there is AND it takes work, patience, and willingness to dig deep to make substantial, lasting changes. When my executive coaching clients moved beyond frenetic busyness and overwhelm and were more productive, what remained was a desire for more from their work and their life.   They wanted to advance their career, be recognized, and love their work. They wanted their work to have value, meaning, and purpose. They wanted to make a living and enjoy their life.   And they were not alone.   So, this is why I took all of the transformational coaching, tools, and strategies I have used for years and designed the Dream Job Masterclass. Have questions? Want to know what my Masterclass is all about? Sign up for my FREE webinar this Thursday,12/10,  at  https://hubs.li/H0C8Qnd0!

Here is what is worrying me (among other things): recommendation letters. There is a history of such letters being written for teachers to get new positions despite the fact that these teachers have abused students.  We often are less than honest (if omission counts) when we write letters of recommendation.  We assume receivers of letters can read between the lines and know that we are not truly recommending someone but we are being cautious to avoid charges of defamation, libel and other legal risks.   So, posit this hypothetical: write a recommendation letter for Bill O'Reilly.  What should it say? Would all references to sexual abuse/harassment be absent from such a letter?  Ponder this conundrum; recommendation letters are commonplace.

Andrew Luck, star quarterback of the Indianapolis Colts, shocked the world Saturday night when he announced his retirement from football--at the age of 29. Why would Luck, one of the best quarterbacks on one of the best teams in the NFL, a man who easily could have earned hundreds of millions of dollars over the next decade, retire at an age most would consider his physical prime? In a brief press conference, Luck gave us a glimpse into his thought process. He helped us to understand how a man who makes millions of dollars to play the game that he loves can easily walk away. And in the process, he teaches a major lesson in emotional intelligence. #EmotionalIntelligence   #leadership   #management   #BestAdvice   #PersonalDevelopment   #careers   #GrowthMindset   #Colts   #AndrewLuck   #EQApplied   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

post_b.text:
Let’s be honest: 2020 has been a sh*tshow. 💩 But a year from now, your life and career could look entirely different. Use the power of  #visualization  to pen a letter to your future self and be sure to: Make it aspirational 🌟 Don’t be afraid to dream big. To achieve something you never had, you need to do something you’ve never done, and right now, that might mean dropping your limiting beliefs and closed  #mindset . Consider this: if all the bad events of 2020 can happen, why can’t the pendulum swing the other direction? Make it specific 🎯 When you have  #clarity  about your future, you can more easily envision it. Imagine it’s September 2021—what, specifically, do you hope to be celebrating? What do your life and career look like? Challenge yourself to be curious about the possibilities. Make it positive 👍 With so much negativity thrown at us in 2020, it’s easy to dwell on what’s gone wrong. And that’s okay, as long as you use looking back as a chance to learn. Use that information to reframe your experiences in a positive manner to help you make  #progress  and envision your  #goals . The beauty of writing your future self a letter is that you control the narrative. And this is one story that is sure to have a happy ending.✨ #leadership   #career   #perspective

I think the answer is no,” Mr. Musk told an online audience Tuesday during The Wall Street Journal’s CEO Council annual summit. “Spend less time on finance, spend less time in conference rooms, less time on PowerPoint and more time just trying to make your product as amazing as possible.” If the customer isn't delightfully disappointed in your product - because as excellent as your product is, you haven't yet delivered the amazing product they don't even KNOW they need YET, you're not doing your job, and your competitors are going to eat you alive.  #leadership   #OneTeam   #DayOne

Debates continue to rage over whether flattening the curve will help, whether economic costs will be worse than human lives, whether hydroxychloroquine will help, whether the BCG vaccine is protecting India, whether the recovery will be V/U/W/L-shaped, whether making noise and lighting lamps help lift spirits... I have managed to stay away from all of them because I DON'T KNOW. What I DO know for sure (to borrow Oprah's phrase) is that a virus, by definition, is contagious, so we need to avoid future waves. That we need to not only change our habits, but we need a system to slow it down.  I believe the  #AarogyaSetu  app is built on good technology to help alert us when we are close to people who are infectious. So I have installed it.  I encourage you to do the same. #sundaythoughts

‪Reminder to new and old creators, don’t give up.  ✏️ Do you remember your first writing post?  🍗 Yeah, it was crap. ‬ ‪Did you stop?  No, I wrote more and I realised it’s more about how to articulate the message.  ‪🎙 Do you remember your first speaking gig?  🍗 Yeah, I was full of nerve. ‬ ‪Did you stop?  No, I spoke more and gain confidence. ‬ 📸 Do you remember your first video?  🍗 Yeah, It’s pretty cringe watching it now. Did you stop?  No, hundred of videos later it helped me develop channels on Snapchat and LinkedIn. It enabled me to travel and connect with amazing people.  💰 Do you remember making your first sale?  🍗 Yeah, I failed to articulate my value. Plus I definitely undervalued my worth.  Did you stop?  No, I realised it’s not pitching on the first “date”, it’s about building that trust. Plus being a trusted voice of authority helps.  — We’re in the middle of lockdown and I see the age of experts becoming content creators.  You can either consume or create. This is the time: 🍗 step up and experiment.  🍗 find your voice. 🍗 be a leader  This is the time to realign yourself and think ... what will the next chapter of life look like?  All you need to do is create.  Who here is with me? 👍 or 👎 #stringtheory  on  #life

Do you measure work experience in number of years? Do you think it's the right way to do it? While intuitively I knew I shouldn't just count the number of years since I started working as experience, I read a book recently that provided a better alternative. It's experience only if one targets, measures, reviews and reflects. Ask 'what could I have done better?' after every project. The book also talked about 'learning cycles' where one participates from the start of the project to the end. The fact that I am still thinking about what I learnt from the book means it was time well spent, especially since I don't read career management books. Link to author's article on the book below. How do you measure work experience? How will this change in future?  Look forward to your thoughts. #workexperience #askingbetterquestions #futureofwork

I slipped a note into my  #gratitudejar  this morning, thanking my mother Eloise Jones for modeling strength, courage and sheer will for me. I think it’s why I’ve been able to embrace the extraordinary adventures and opportunities life has tossed at me—while surviving the crushing blows and defeats.  So it’s fitting that I’m sitting at Gate A10 at Charlotte Douglas International Airport now, awaiting the first leg of another long journey. I’m also grateful that in this 400th anniversary of the first African’s presence in this country, I’m about to spend most of  #BlackHistoryMonth2019  on the African continent. I’m listening to  #Homegoing  by  #YaaGyasi  on  Audible, Inc.  now. It’s giving me chills. Can’t wait to see what this journey holds. #Africa   #Mamaland   #gratitude   #BlackHistory   #AfricanAmericans   #AfricanAmericanHistory   #queeninthequeencity 👑  #TheAncestors

Chan School of Public Health . Dr. Crear-Perry has addressed the  United Nations  Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights ( UNOCHA ) in order to push for a  #humanrights  framework to improve the dire global statistics around  #maternalmortality , She has served as the Executive Director of the  Birthing Project USA , Director of Women's and Children's Services at Jefferson Community Healthcare Center and as Director of Clinical Services for the City of New Orleans Health Department. Dr. Crear-Perry also serves as an advisory committee member of the Black Mamas Matter Alliance, a Black women-led, cross-sectoral alliance that empowers Black mothers to advocate, drive research, build power and shift culture for Black maternal health, rights and justice. For more information about the Maternal Health Task Force, check out this link--->  https://www.mhtf.org / #birthequity   #maternahealth   #reproductivehealth   #reproductiverights   #reproductivejustice   #globalhealth   #HealthForAll

In case you missed it: Farmers Can Opt Out Of The ACA... But how are they to pay for their broken legs, diabetes and pregnancies? No problem as long as they have cash. The Farm Bureau  will be allowed to sell skimpy health care coverage while offering false hope of good quality health insurance to its members . Farm Bureau officials estimated that about 42,000 people would eventually take its coverage and promised lower rates than plans complying with federal mandates. They believed the takers would be individuals without coverage or struggling to pay for individual coverage. I hope that ‘life on the farm’ is as healthy as it sounds since the new insurance coverage might not pan out the way it’s been sold to the farming community. Selected Excerpt: “...The Farm Bureau would be able to set higher rates or reject coverage for people who have pre-existing medical conditions. They also suggested that coverage could be limited for large expenses, such as a pregnancy or cancer treatment.”

I had watched the documentary ‘Jane’ a couple of years back. It chronicles the life of Jane Goodall and her dedication to making the world aware of the potential of Chimpanzees and the perils they face. I was both inspired and moved. It made me think how one person can create a large impact, one step at a time, one day at a time. Can you imagine the passion and dedication that she has! She spent more than 60 years relentlessly focused on one cause. She made a big difference to my own understanding of nature and our origins and the need to share this planet with all living things.  I have just begun reading the book ‘Be Fearless: 5 Principles for a Life of Breakthroughs and Purpose’. The book lays emphasis on overcoming our fears and doing what we know is right. Each one of us is capable of making a difference. Use your fear to gather the courage to do what seems impossible in unimaginable ways.  #WhatInspiresMe   #InspiringPeople   #Inspiration

post_b.text:
In 2017, I got into a huge argument with my co-founders at the time. We ended up separating. Here's where I went wrong 👇🏾 ❌ I was a **** and said hurtful things that I didn't need to.  ❌ I only cared that I believed that I was right. Not about their feelings. Not that they were human beings. Here is what I've learned and how I've adjusted since then: ✅ I don't manage teams anymore. I'm not good at it. I only step in when I need to. I am more aware of the kind of person I am. I'm blunt. I tell it how it is and I have a lot of passion.  ✅ Everyone on the team (and I mean everyone) should feel safe. Safe to bring ideas to the table. Safe to fail. Safe to try new things. That's where innovation comes from. I used to be a tyrant of a leader. And now, I honestly learn more from watching and working with my team than they probably learn from me. ✅ It's not always about being right or being wrong. Sometimes it's just about being human. A great read if you're looking to grow a powerhouse team (in any industry) is the Culture Code by Daniel Coyle. That way you don't have to make the mistakes that I did. 😅 People are your greatest asset. Take care of them. #justQ  🖖🏾🖤  #business   #entrepreneurship

Mine are: Mrs Allsop - she taught me as a junior but importantly she taught me to read books. Not read but to read books (I need to do More) because she read to us at the end of every day from the classics with fond memories. My brother who is no Longer with us but who taught me some of the practical skills that have stayed with me for life and that you are not limited by your start in life. A colleague Ken Kneale who very early in my career taught me basics of CCTV but also converted me from this straight line engineer to a thinker outside the box and as an apprentice  Steven Howarth  who is still the best engineer at hiding cables in the business. My friend and best man  Neil Hussey   who brought me out of myself. And current colleagues  Patrick Jefferies Dip GAI   James Harvey   Duncan Rigby FBLI   Roy Buckingham Dip.GAI Reg.AI M.InstAI   Rory Grant   Pip Courcoux   That I’m still learning at 51 but I also  hope I’ve had some influence with people I’ve worked with in the past and present.  Don’t forget people who helped and influenced you on the way through life.

We are in the midst of the holiday season! As we approach the new year, I want to reflect on all that has happened in the past twelve months. I had a chance to travel the world, visiting beautiful countries like The United Kingdom, Australia, Thailand, and others! I released my second book, Indistractable, to an outpouring of support from all over the world. I had the opportunity to serve and impact many people through my work, resulting in recognition as a LinkedIn Top Voice in Tech for 2019 and nominations for other accolades. Above all else, I began to take back control of my attention, my time, and my life, leading to countless memories made with my family, friends, and loved ones. Through it all, I have emerged endlessly grateful for all that I am able to do and enjoy on a daily basis. I will continue to approach my work and my relationships with the same optimism that I have in the past. 2019 has been great! I have a feeling that 2020 will be even better. To you, my digital community, I say thank you for an incredible year. Happy Holidays and Happy New Year! I’ll see you in 2020! 👋 #Indistractable   #HappyHolidays   #Gratitude   #Reflection

We are on the brink of autonomous car displacement, which is on the brink of flying car disruption, which is on the brink of Hyperloop & rockets-to-anywhere decimation. Plus, avatars & robots. post_a.text:
For many years I worked in a high-volume, urban ED. I treated people--who became patients--for everything you could imagine: a fork stuck in an eyeball causing an ocular rupture, a nose bleed that put a person into volume shock because of how much blood was lost, abdominal pain that turned out to be an ectopic pregnancy, an achy leg which turned out to be a fractured femur...and on and on and on. Sure, I also saw people seek 'emergency care' for heartburn, lice, sexually transmitted diseases, skin lesions, mild sunburns and on and on and on..... But how on earth can we expect the 'lay public' to know when to seek emergency treatment and when not to?  Honestly--think about this..many people do not have primary care doctors so they come to the ED...many people do not want to wait weeks for an appointment to see a doctor so they come to the ED...many people don't know if they are truly sick or not truly sick...so they come to us. Until there is more access to care in communities where people live, then we will always have people coming to the ED--whether they should or not...and we need to cover the costs.

post_b.text:
Here's why becoming Indistractable is the skill of the century 👇  When it comes to living healthy and productive lives, it's not that we don't know what to do.  We all know a salad is healthier than a piece of cake.  We all know regular exercise can help us live longer.  We all know how important it is to have quality time with our family.  It's not that we don't know what to do. It's that we keep getting distracted from the things we WANT to do.  To be indistractable, we have to make time for the things that matter most. post_a.text:
Mornings are stressful. No matter how much sleep you get, it seems like you’re always still tired when your alarm goes off. If you’re like most people, you spend some time checking your phone to see what you missed on social media while you were sleeping and see what emails have already started cluttering your inbox. You may not even have time to eat breakfast, but you always overdose on caffeine. You rush to get ready, have to deal with traffic, and arrive late to the office. Then, for the rest of the day, your schedule is dictated by your overflowing inbox. You don’t feel in control of your life. You feel like you’re living out the expectations others have set for you. You feel frantic, rushed, and you struggle to complete any truly meaningful work. A bad morning can hijack the rest of your day. Does this sound familiar? If so, you need a better morning routine! These habits are probably ones you’ve been following for years, but it’s never too late to make a change. You can get out of the morning rut that’s hindering your progress during the rest of the day. The first 90 minutes after you wake up are absolutely crucial. If you start your day strong, you’ll be more focused and productive. Four Habits to Successfully Reclaim Your Morning...

When I was 20 a woman came into the gym that I was working at. Long story, but she ended up telling me things like: ✅ You will be making minimum wage for the rest of your life. ✅ You'll never be as successful as me. ✅ Colleges shouldn't waste scholarship money on people like you. ✅ Etc. I want to thank that woman. Because it was in that moment that I decided that if she is what "success" meant... then I didn't want it. If I had to put other people down to make myself feel big then I didn't want it. I quit that day and found a social media internship a few weeks later.  The rest is history.  Define your own success. #justQ  🖖🏽🖤  #StrangeOnPurposePodcast   #Business 📸 Justin Jackson

post_b.text:
As leaders, we’re often asked to choose sides, but solutions and issues are rarely confined to one side. The most successful leaders use duality not to choose this OR that but to integrate this AND that. Here’s how:   Acknowledge that duality is everywhere.    From technical expertise and “soft skills,” to traditional methods and innovative processes, to seasoned employees and new hires, duality is inherent in business.   Adopt a growth mindset.   Open yourself up to new possibilities beyond the status quo, challenging yourself to seek out all sides of an issue.   “Embrace the suck” of vulnerability.   Get comfortable being uncomfortable. Far too many leaders allow fear (of the unknown, of being judged or ridiculed) to dictate their choices.   Maintain intellectual humility.   Move away from preconceived notions and consider new possibilities and creative solutions by recognizing that what you think and believe might be wrong.   Solicit the opinions of those outside your usual circle.   Open yourself up to considering new ideas from unfamiliar sources and engage in discussions with people who don’t share your views or background.   #leadership   #career   #duality

post_a.text:
Taking action is the one surefire antidote to combat career anxiety, doubt and fear. Here’s how to get—and keep—moving: Turn those “What if?” questions from negative to positive. When we focus on the negative what-ifs—“What if I fail?” and “What if I embarrass myself?”—we remain in a vicious cycle of inertia and perceived inadequacy. But when we shift our mindset and turn those what-ifs into positive questions—“What if I succeed?” and “What if I inspire someone?”—we envision the possibilities and more easily welcome new outcomes. To grow, you need courage; courage requires taking action.  Sad but true: There is no growth in the status quo. If you'd like to progress in your career, sooner or later you need to break out of your comfort zone. Challenging yourself to leave your cocoon helps you stretch your wings and gain new skills, experience, and confidence. Action begets more action—and success. When you use awareness to make action an intentional habit, you train yourself to continue to take action. Over time, those small changes in behavior creatively shake things up and breathe new life into old methods and routines. And combined with focused action, that newfound clarity will bring you something even better: success. #leadership   #career   #action   #positivity   #fear 
 
 
 …see more

post_a.text:
Both Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Microsoft cofounder Bill Gates recently weighed in with their thoughts, and they're almost polar opposite reactions. On Friday, Musk tweeted: "The coronavirus panic is dumb" In contrast, Gates said the following in an article recently posted on his blog: "In the past week, COVID-19 has started to behave a lot like the once-in-a-century pathogen we've been worried about. I hope it's not that bad, but we should assume that it will be until we know otherwise." You can really see how stark the contrast is of these two responses when you place them side by side: Musk: "The coronavirus panic is dumb" Gates: "I hope it's not that bad, but we should assume that it will be until we know otherwise." Musk and Gates both possess brilliant minds. But while one of these responses is potentially dangerous, the other promotes a rational, "safety-first" mentality--and could possibly lead to saving millions of lives. (Read more in today's column.) #leadership   #management   #Tesla   #Microsoft   #EmotionalIntelligence   #coronavirus   #COVID19   #innovation   #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

post_a.text:
When it comes to planning our schedule, where do we begin?  The common approach is to make a to-do list. We write down all the things we want to do and hope we’ll find the time throughout the day to do them. Anyone who has tried keeping such a list knows many tasks tend to get pushed one day to the next, and the next. In order to become indistractable, we must plan our schedules around values. We should ask ourselves, “how would the person I want to become spend their time?” When we don’t make time for our values, we unintentionally spend too much time in one area of our life at the expense of others. If we chronically neglect our values, we become someone we’re not proud of—our life feels out of balance and diminished.  Ironically, this ugly feeling makes us more likely to seek distractions to escape our dissatisfaction without actually solving the problem. The outbreak of COVID-19 has given us all plenty of time to consider the things we value. Maybe it’s spending more time with our loved ones. Maybe it’s spending more time in prayer or meditation. Whatever it may be, we can all emerge out of this with a renewed understanding of our values.  #Indistractable   #Scheduling   #Values   #COVID19

You know the expression: Truth is stranger than fiction?  Sadly, that describes the American presidency at present. If you made up what was happening over the past 10 days, people would tell you that your story was too far fetched, too far from a real situation and to revise what you wrote so it was believable.   My question: what do you do when, in fact, truth is stranger (and worse) than fiction?  How do you change the course of an off-course tanker truck?  How do you restore belief in justice and fairness and the rule of law.  Whatever that path is, we need to find it -- now.  From lies to leaks, from disclosures to drama, from cover-up to conspiracy, how do we bring back balance to our nation and its people?  Think.  We need answers.

post_b.text:
I recently had the pleasure of speaking with  Ozan Varol  about his upcoming book, Think Like a Rocket Scientist.  In Ozan's own words, the book lays out, "nine simple strategies from rocket science that you can use to make giant leaps in work and life—whether it’s landing your dream job, accelerating your business, or creating the next breakthrough product." One of the more interesting parts of our conversation was learning about his view on the "fail fast, fail often" mantra. When we fail, we tend to assign blame to external factors—customers, competitors, and so on. Instead, Ozan says, we should aim to learn fast, because "failure can be the best teacher if you approach it properly." We also discussed the book writing process, other interesting parts of behavior science, and more. His research and work have also become especially relevant as we continue to navigate the COVID-19 pandemic.  I've included a link in the comments. Tag a colleague and let me know which part of the interview you found most insightful. #indistractable   #thinklikearocketscientist   #strategicfailure

I puked in the bathroom before my first speaking engagement. 🤯 This conversation was one of my favorites on any podcast, and they were all in high school. There is so much comparison out there. Especially from aspiring speakers. Here's what I think is important for people to know: ✅ I dropped out of a public speaking class on the first day because I found out you had to give speeches... 🤷🏽‍♂️ When I started speaking about things that I was passionate about it was a lot more fun.  ✅ I still get nervous. I've just reverse engineered my state of flow  / mode that I go into when I'm speaking or on camera. So those nerves don't effect me anymore. ✅ I am not a good speaker naturally. I've worked at it. I'm still working at it and I don't ever think that journey will end. Doesn't matter how big or small the stages are. There is always more room for growth. What are some of you speaking tips? Video is a progressive storytelling skill. What do I mean that?  We strive for perfection, thinking that it's the best outcome. But when it comes to video, doing 1% better on each video will help grow faster. Progress is a healthier approach.  Just like what I'm doing with my YouTube channel.  I created this intro video, before it was 15 seconds now I've cut it to 5 seconds.  I love doing videos, but since focusing on The Trusted Voice, I had slow down my video creation and work on my startup.  Still, I release once a week, a video to help you grow your brand. Trauma informed is not enough.  Trauma sensitive and trauma responsive are needed in schools, workplaces and communities.  This isn’t a political issues folks.  Shootings and fear and trauma don’t carry an R or D on them.

post_b.text:
The overarching cultural concept behind a Japanese tea ceremony is ichi-go ichi-e, which, roughly translated, means “one time, one place.”  This phrase serves to remind its participants to cherish the gathering, for the meeting may not have the chance to be repeated. Even if the attendees met again, the dynamics would shift, and thus, the experience would never be the same. In this way, each meeting is unique and to be treasured. It’s important to note that a tea ceremony was designed to make this concept possible by asking its participants—samurai and wealthy noblemen, as well as farmers and everyday people—to come together as equals.  In the tea house, no one outranks another, and everyone has something to contribute. To enter the tea house, one must leave one’s non-essentials (the samurai’s sword and helmet, for example) outside and then pass through an intentionally low opening, bowing as one does so. This physical act of leaving behind extraneous possessions and lowering your head is another reminder to be present. In our increasingly divisive and chaotic world, perhaps it’s time for all of us to embrace the ichi-go ichi-e mindset. #leadership   #trust   #listening   #present 
 
 
 …see more

post_a.text:
As countless Americans suddenly need to balance working from home with everyday life, it's natural that they begin to feel symptoms of burnout. That's exactly why Google and Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai decided to give his people a gift: A well-deserved day off. Pichai elaborated in a recent email to staff (first reported by CNBC): "I know many of us have been running hard non-stop for a [sic] weeks now and may be experiencing some burnout. So, I also used TGIF [a companywide meeting] as a chance to announce an official day off on May 22. "Take the time to do whatever you need to do to prioritize your well-being." At first look, it's a simple gesture. But this decision is actually a brilliant lesson in emotional intelligence, the ability to identify, understand, and manage emotions. Let's break down three reasons why. (Read more in today's column.) #google   #leadership   #management   #coronavirus   #COVID19   #mentalhealth   #burnout   #EmotionalIntelligence #MakeEmotionsWorkForYouNotAgainstYou

post_b.text:
I remember sitting in my dorm room Freshman year. My roommate never showed up so I had a double all to myself. One of the students down the hall was in my room. "Do you want to go to this party with us?" "I'm good dude. I'll be writing all night." I responded. "That's kind of cool. By the time you get out of this place you'll have a bunch of work to show." Looking back, I can't tell you why I wrote those stories. Or why I wrote music. Or why I played video games. I just did things because they interested me. I was obsessed with those things and I never concerned myself with things that didn't interest me. Last night I was in my old Google Drive and found some of those stories. And they inspired me a little bit. I left myself a note on the top of one of the books I was writing: "Just write. Edit later. Just get shit down. Understand it will suck. But the ideas are always good. There is no wrong. Write! It’s the only way to create something beautiful. It’s a lot easier to edit what’s already there." During this time, when people are learning new skills and jumping back into things that interest them... Just write (figuratively). Worry about editing later. Worry about the plan later. #justQ  🖖🏽🖤 
 
 
 …see more

post_b.text:
People are really good at saying what they want.  We say we want to be good parents. We say we want to be good partners.  We say we want to make time for prayer or meditation. We say we want to exercise more and eat healthier. When it comes to living in accordance with our values, we have to be able to say “yes” to this one question: Did I make time for this on my calendar? In order to follow-through on our promises to ourselves and our loved ones, it’s not enough to just talk the talk. To be the people we want to become, we have to schedule time to live out our values.  We have to turn our values into time! What's something you're making more time for in the new year? Is it on your calendar? #Indistractable   #Values   #Purpose

post_a.text:
I just did my first TEDx talk! 😍 Which is crazy to me because I literally puked in the bathroom a few minutes before my first speaking engagement a little over a year ago. And now, nerves don't effect me because of this 👇🏽 I learned this from Kobe Bryant and people like Michael  Phelps: When Kobe was still in the NBA he created this on court persona, the Black Mamba. Off the court, Kobe had to deal with everyday life issues. But on the court, Black Mamba's only focus was dominating on the court. And having that mental separation, and focus, is something that's helped me as an athlete, musician, and now as a speaker.  1). Having a routine that helps me get into my zone. 2). Creating a persona that reminds me that it's okay to be nervous. Because the minute that I step on stage the nerves will turn into focus. 3). When it's time to perform, just hit "play" on your tape. The tape being all the preparation you've had up until this point and the routine that you've perfected (Michael Phelps does this). That's why nerves no longer effect me.  What's your prep look like? #justQ  🖖🏽🖤

post_b.text:
Former Reserve Bank of India governor YV Reddy could save the banking system from the impact of Lehman collapse but India’s microfinance industry—which had been growing at a breakneck speed—got almost wiped out. The event came to pass when the promulgation of a state law in Andhra Pradesh, the hotbed of microfinance, put severe restrictions on its activities. In 2010, SKS Microfinance Ltd got itself listed on the bourses, the second microfinance entity globally to do so after Banco Compartamos in Mexico in 2007, but months after that the Andhra Pradesh law nearly killed SKS and many others. If you want to know what exactly happened in India’s growing microfinance industry, read ‘From Lehman to Demonetization’. The book dissects the crisis triggered by the Andhra Pradesh law, the industry’s journey through hell and back, and its display of maturity and resilience. However, not everyone has learned lessons from the crisis and hence we see new hotspots. Demonetization and frequent farm loan waivers have also impacted their health. It catches all these and offers pointers to the future.   To read the book:  http://amzn.to/2AucbeQ

post_b.text:
Have you ever played that game, “Two Truths and a Lie?”💁‍♀️ For those unfamiliar, you offer three “facts” about yourself and have other players guess which two are accurate and which one is a fib. For instance, if we were playing right now (and hey, why not?), mine might be: 1️⃣ Guy Fieri told me I smelled great 2️⃣ My face once appeared on Go-Gurt® 3️⃣ Like most creatives, I’m an introvert The whole point is to *intentionally* throw someone off, so they’re never quite sure who you are and what you’re about. You leave them scratching their heads, not sure what to believe.🤷‍♀️ While inciting confusion is a potentially game-winning strategy, it’s a lousy way to make professional progress. Because when you confuse, you lose—a potential employer’s interest, your boss’s attention, or a prospective client who doesn’t understand how you can help them.🤦‍♀️ (Ouch!) So, what should you do instead?  If you got my latest  #IlluminateMe  newsletter, you’d already know.😉 Subscribe to get real-world takeaways you can immediately apply to your life and career delivered directly to your inbox.📥 (And to find out if you guessed correctly! ✅) Find the link in the comments below.⤵️ #leadership   #career   #communication   #clarity

i have come to the conclusion that risk cannot be reduced. at best it is displaced, and most times, it is displaced in ways that makes it hidden, which is dangerous. this realization has been a long time coming. anyhoo, now, whenever i am on the receiving end of a pitch from a startup team telling me they are eliminating risk because “blah blah blah technology” i either turn into the vengeful Odin and claim half of the team for Valhalla and ultimately Ragnarok, or i gently explain that risk is never eliminated, it is merely displaced. now, depending on how and where it is displaced, i may invest or i may not.

Can't believe I'll be hitching a ride from Little Rock to Hot Springs for the  Journalism and Women Symposium (JAWS)  Fall Camp 2017 with the  the named plaintiff in Boylan v. Times, the 1974 federal class-action suit filed on behalf of 550 women at  The New York Times  over inequities including pay, assignments and advancement. That case  literally paved the way for more women to move into leadership positions in American newsrooms.   She was the first woman copy editor at the Times, and throughout her distinguished career she has fought continuously for women and people of color to be "in the room where it happens."  She's  Betsy Wade . And she's still a hoot.  Thanks to Betsy, and  Roxanne Foster , and  Kira Zalan  and   Glenda Holste  for welcoming me back into the #JAWS fold. #JAWSCamp2017 #journalism #women #mentoring

post_a.text:
I have been doing a lot of thinking lately about how the government spends money -- how it allocates its dollars (our dollars).  I have been struck by the no-bid Cerner contract with the VA to move to electronic health records which is estimated to cost $16 billion.  No typo.  See:  https://lnkd.in/e-bR3RW .   So, here's my question: What can you get for $16 billion if we had other spending priorities?  What disease could we cure for that amount?  Could we have universal early childhood education for that amount?  We have legislation with mandates that are unfunded; suppose we looked at some of those to fund?  A recent NY Times piece noted the proliferation of child pornography on the web and the absence of sufficient resources allocated to stomping out this problem. The legislation exists; the dollars don't. Bottom line: How can a private company get a $16 billion no bid contract when we have so many other needs?   Ask yourself: What can $16 billion buy? 
 
 
 …see more

post_b.text:
Views 🆚 Trust What do you prefer? There’s two types of content:  🍭 One is candy  The views  The laughter  The sugar hits  The dopamine  Candy focuses on content that generates views and virality   For views focus on polls and written status posts.  If we do the maths you can generate 30,000 views per month by posting 30 times - that’s 1000 views each :)  Super doable right?  🥗 The second is substance  Think of vegetable that nourishes the mind and body. The value add The long term play  The Expert type  The trust factor  Video generally has lesser views but the trust is generally higher.  This is a good play and focus if you want to position as an authority in your space.  So 🥗 or 🍭? What kind of content do you prefer others to consume?  Me... I just like 🍗 Best of both worlds ha  #stringtheory  on  #branding   #personalbranding

During the  #socialdistancing , I was drawn to my best companion, books! I read 12 books in the last couple of months (thanks to my Audible) and walked for miles every day, another activity that makes me calm and gets me to my zone.  I thought to share the list of these books with you to inspire you to use this  #quarantine  time to read, learn, and get into your performance and productivity zone. Out of these 12 books my favorites were:  1) Originals by  Adam Grant 2) Trillion Dollar Coach - Bill Campbell's Leadership Style  3) Trailblazer by  Marc Benioff 4) Power Up by  Magdalena Yesil 5) The Power of Habit by  Charles Duhigg   Anyone else read any of these books? What was your thought? Any other good books that you want to add to this list? Please share your thoughts.  #inspiration   #books   #bookrecommendation   #leadership   #businessinsight   #businessbooks   #powerofmind   #positivethinking

post_a.author: Shelly Palmer

post_b.text:
For  #FlashbackFriday , yesterday at 3:50 am, when my  #BFF   Faith T.  drove me to the airport for my  #Detroit  flight. I felt guilty asking the favor, but she just said, “What are  #friends  for?” Well, the best investment you can make in life is to pick really authentic, trustworthy, principled, generous, brave, supportive people to be your friends. You have to see the best part of yourself in them, and make sure they can do the same with you. I’ve known Faith since 1979, and she's the same vibrant, positive and selfless person I met at  Northwestern University . She's a realtor with  Keller Williams Realty - Charlotte South Park , and recently, she was the only woman on an expert  #affordablehousing   panel hosted by  Bank of America . I may be biased, but she was clearly the star. Back in January, my friend  Lisa Grace Lednicer  spoke during a workshop panel I was leading for  The Aspen Institute , carving time from her busy schedule as an editor at  The Washington Post  and an adjunct professor at the University of Maryland . I returned the favor by speaking to one of her classes. Seeing Lisa blossom from the striving young St. Petersburg Times reporter in 1988 to the confident, impassioned woman she is today is wonderfully enriching for me. PICK. GREAT. FRIENDS. I CAN'T SAY IT ENOUGH.

post_a.text:
When we think of  #pioneers , inventors, we think of them mostly as men. But history is replete with bold women who break the mold. Bertha Benz is one of them, in none other than the Automobile industry. Historically, the  #automotiveindustry  has been driven by men.  Mary Barra  became the first female CEO of  General Motors .  But Bertha Benz was a woman who defied convention then and today.    Her husband, Karl Benz, was the inventor. She was the  #Investor ! She firmly believed in an automobile's opportunity when it was never considered a means of transportation. She was the business partner and also held the Patent rights though her name as a woman was not allowed on it. She was the first person to drive an automobile over a long distance ever (5 August 1888), rigorously field testing the patent Motorwagen, inventing brake pads, and solving several practical issues during the 65 miles (105 km) trip. She brought the Benz Patent-Motorwagen worldwide attention and got the company its first sales.   Karl Benz wrote the following in his memoirs: "Only one person remained with me in the small ship of life when it seemed destined to sink. That was my wife. Bravely and resolutely, she set the new sails of  #hope ." #Inspiration   #Innovation   Video Credits:  Mercedes-Benz USA

post_b.text:
In the workplace, effectively communicating authentic appreciation and encouragement isn’t one-size-fits-all, nor is it restricted to a single language of appreciation.  The best way to express your gratitude in the workplace starts with asking others their preferences so you can better relate to one another and deepen your relationships. There are five languages of workplace  #appreciation : Words of Affirmation, Quality Time, Acts of Service, Tangible Gifts, and Appropriate Physical Touch. This week, we’ve broken down how to effectively communicate using them, actions you can take to support each style, and things to avoid. #5: APPROPRIATE PHYSICAL TOUCH🖐 How To Communicate This language uses appropriate physical touch to demonstrate appreciation. Actions To Take Offer a high five, handshake, fist bump, or a pat on the back when acknowledging someone for a great job. These spontaneous displays of celebration help build positive work-based relationships. Things To Avoid Personal boundaries are important to keep in mind with this language of appreciation, so avoid unwanted touch. #leadership   #communication
